reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a review for the build up to this point. I will write something more comprehensive when it's at release. This game has an absolutely fantastic shell for a great game. The gameplay feels wonderful, the textures and visuals are top notch, the simplistic yet addictive item/loot/stats systems all work. The random generation of worlds is passable (although still could about ten times as many prefab chunks.

HOWEVER.

It's extremely light on content. I don't know if that's because they are leaving that to last, however i blew though this game in 18 minutes. And I did not rush. I did die about 20 times before I finished it, so my total playtime is a few hours. That is still absolutely horrible compared to ANY other game of this type out there. Even very cheaply made games like rouge shooter have 100 times more content than this game. It needs more levels. Bigger levels. More items, more scaling. Etc.

It's like a demo version of a game. And I am kind of scared that they are just going to tweak systems until release, instead of releasing actual game length.

The game needs to be streatched across a wider canvas, make the drops scale very slowly upwards, make the levels huge with multi areas leading to the floor down, so we can explore sprawling levels if we wish, instead of these tinny little dungeons. Right now, because this game has the core mechanics of a 10/10 indie game. I am going to recommend this game. However if the content is the same as it is now, at release. Then I'll be changing my recommendation.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is amazing. Been playing it since it was in it's Alpha stages and was free and since then this game has improved A TON. Every run is randomly generated and you never know what you're going to find or have to go up against. Every level you go gets harder and harder and if you don't have very good gear or arnt leveled up alot, then you're not going to last very long (Especially on the trip back.) The replayability of this game is great too. It hasnt gotten old and I have yet to beat it. (The trip back is extremely hard if you don't have alot of HP pots, Good wands and really good armor.) I give it a 9/10. Definitely worth my $8.

PS: This game is still in beta, but the Devs seem to have some great ideas coming up like shops, more levels, classes and other things. So if you're worried about content, stop worrying. There's alot more to come and this game has a ton of potential.

EDIT: (11/30/2014) The game is still being updated and is still improving drastically. With the addition of 2 hand slots and destructable boxes along with a ton of new room layouts (Namely the caves, they've been completely re-done to look 100 times better.) Everything i've said before still stands and i'd still reccomend getting this. It's a great buy!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Amazing mix of a 2D Dungeon RPG (think Link to the Past for SNES) and Doom. The game starts you with a random inventory (one weapon, one food, one magic item, and some gold) and you can talk to a few NPCs to hear about the dangerous dungeon ahead. You head inside and explore the dungeon killing enemies and collecting progressively better loot until eventually, you die. When you respawn, thinking that all hope is lost, you realize that your gold from your previous life is still with you. You also realize, going into the dungeon, that it's different each time. The Camp where the npcs live in the beginning has many shops and the dungeon is endless and randomly generated. You can collect and save your gold to buy better loot in the town or just find as much as you can before you're killed in the dungeon. No matter how you play, delver is a great, addictive, cheap and fun retro dungeon-adventure game that everyone should play
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
OTHER REASONS TO BUY

Epic Pixel Graphics
Level Editor
Still in Beta (so much more to come)
its CHEAP (4 dollars when i bought it, normally 8)
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
EVERYONE TRY DELVER!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm no fan of early access games, but actually, this one is a definite exception to the rule. I got this in the Roguelike 2 Humble Bundle (so it was something like £4 for this and other rougelikes), but this was the game I was looking forward to. I'll quickly list some pros, cons, and then my experience.

Pro:
• Really good combat system with a focus on timing (nice balance of annoying bats and poison worms, and non-annoying enemies).
• Levelling up and getting loot works well. You sometimes get a rare piece of kit, which makes you feel like god for a few floors.
• Very attractive game (although there  could be a little room for improvement in some of the room details), chunky pixels are officially cool. The first, second and final themes work really well. The third theme is a little pedestrian - and so dark you just can't see anything in it.
• Music is great, very fitting but not in-your-face-y.

Con:
• Foremost: almost all of the game is just so dark. There needs to be a 'Scroll of Light', or an update making the Candle light up the world a little more. In the third 'theme' (I won't spoil it), it's so dark that you often can't see any monsters, especially as only a few pixels aren't hiding in the water.
• Jesus christ, the poison goes on for years.
• Very little point in not choosing to level up HP when you get the choice. I went from 8HP to 38HP (ish) in one run-through, and if you wear the armour you just find, you basically don't need to worry. If you don't, then the poison (above) will easily kill you.
• No way to block with your shield? And also, 2handed weapons don't seem to do any more damage, to make up for not having a shield? And - equipping books as a shield feels like it should do something, but no notes anywhere make it clear what (if anything) having a book equipped does.
• Regardless of the above things: I finished the game in my first run-through. If you can't be bothered (e.g. at the end of the fourth 'theme'), you can simply run past enemies and take negligible damage - less so than you would if you tried to fight it, especially seeing regen items are so rare.
• And least importantly: this game is evidently unfinished. I understand it's a roguelike, but it does need a bit more content. If you could fetch the orb, run back to base, then go on another mission (assuming the orb unlocks a 'new' dungeon), that would be cool. Or challenges, modifiers, things to unlock, weapons to start with, etc., that would be awesome. I just feel like I couldn't play through it again. Maybe levelling up should unlock cool spells, or something similar? I don't feel like I need to grind or farm in the dungeon to look for some awesome and rare loot that makes me godlike. It needs something rare like that, or something that unlocks. In my opinion, that's how Risk of Rain is just infinitely replayable.

TL/DR: I still would totally play it again, but it's relatively easy to finish in the first play-through. This game is already good, and I'm assuming it'll be great by the time it's out of Beta! :-)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I requested refund right away.

It's fun for the first little while, but it doesn't take long to figure out that this game lacks any real content.

I decided to research this game (wiki) after playing for a while.
Here's my conclusion.

There's a lack of monster and level diversity, there isn't a huge variety of items, there's no way to sell items (not a huge issue, but still worth mentioning).

The game engine was well made, the dungeons are somewhat fun to explore, but it's easy to see how this game would get repetitive fast. It's strikingly similar to Minecraft, yet different. While Minecraft focuses on exploration and diversity (biomes, items, creatures, etc.), the developers of this game only chose to focus on dungeon exploration with little creativity in respect to monsters, items, and biome.

I understand content takes time to add, but this game is already in beta, lacks a solid update history, and most importantly - diversity in monster, characters, and items. Let's get real, this game has been out since 2013 and it is now 2016 - So where's the content?

While this game may provide fun for a short while, I would stay away from this one until the developers can get their act together.

Consumers work hard for their money and deserve a polished game - this one is just not there yet.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Imagine Minecraft. Now imagine if Notch had made good on his promises to make combat and dungeons, instead of pooing out some placeholders and leaving it to work on other projects.
Now imagine someone took them out, and made them a shortish replayable randomized standalone game, that uses doom-style sprites instead of block models.

That's Delver.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So i felt this game needs a review because of how it good it is (in my opinion). I'll start off by saying that this is a game in which when you die you loose just about everything, i won't tell you what you keep because it defeats the purpose of playing it doesn't it. But this game combines a perfect sense of rogue-like/fps with modular enhancements on the website. The game although being in Early-Acess, which i can already hear the ugggh another one. Yes it is in early access but it being in early access means lots of updates and things to look forward to in the game to make you want to play it even more after each update.

Pros
- It combines rogue-like/rpg style game with a nice combat experience
- Really simple and easy to pick up even just to play around 1 life
- Animations are pretty decent for what it is
- In my opinion its not to hard or too easy it hits that sweet spot that most games don't
- Varying loot is always a thing i love to see and this game has it and like skyrim you want to pick up everything
- Modular (-meaning skins, hopefully in the future other mods)
- It has a random loadout everytime delving into the dungeon that keeps the game refreshing

Things to Improve Upon
- Just some mechanics nothing to important like the save game feature
- I would like to see a bigger camp in the future maybe, just with a bit more options maybe a reward/trophy house of boss another idea
- Steam achievements would be nice so I work towards or find something to it that adds a rewarding experience

Cons
- For an early access not sure it can be counted as a con but it falls short beatable in like 3 hours since i last played it :(
- It's not really rewarding for the outside camp experience to me

Yes it's a good game but there arent many cons i found in my experience of playing it all the way through. I will always look forward to hack and slashing my way to the end again as the game updates. This will definately go on the list of games i follow to see what comes of it. its an easy 7.5/10 :3. Buy it, its like 8$ #worth

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A very interesting blend of dungeon crawl and roguelike, this game has held my attention since I first purchased it.  It's a good addition to your library.  It's simple enough to start playing when you have limited time or attention, but robust enough that you don't feel like you're playing an indie throwaway.  Its randomized levels provide replay value and the ability to stockpile gold between runs allows for you to splurge on a run to give yourself a head start.  Also, the developer is very active.  It's obvious Delver is a labor of love.

Some tips, for new players:
1. Your HP refills when you level up, so stockpile your food in early levels.
2. If you inventory is getting full, leave a treasure trove of food and wands at the ladder down to the next floor.
3. Heavier armor slows you down, but not as much as you might think.
4. When leveling, I prioritize Health > Attack > Speed.  I've never put points into the stats that buff wands or archery.
5. Zombies and caterpillars (but not spiders, as of when I wrote this) will poison you with their attacks.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm enjoying the game immensely.  It's quite simple to pick up and understand, you can play it for 5 minutes or 5 hours and it's always fun.  If you end up dying (which will likely happen a lot for the first few tries) you restart at the camp and go through a new dungeon with randomized equipment to start but gold carries over from each life.  There are 2 shop characters in the camp outside, 1 for general equipment (armor, weapons, potions, etc) and the other for scrolls that might come in handy.  Generally use the wands when you have them and you'll last longer.  Anything ranged works best.

Overall I'd give the game 9/10.  I only drop it by 1 cause it's a little repetitive over time but still quite fun even with the simple graphics which I find perfect for the game and it's style of play.  It's also not a super expensive game and as of the time I played it I didn't notice any bugs through about 6 levels of the dungeon.  Everything seems to function like it's suppose to and makes it a wonderful game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I played this game for a solid three hours right after I got it and never once got bored. Sure, I almost rage quit a couple times, but that's just video games. I like that you dont customize your character because if you did you would be way more upset with dying (which you do QUITE A BIT). No two dungeons are the same, and you face new challenges and get new rewards with every delve into the myserious ruins. Some rooms are the same each play (just the rooms with transition ladders, however), yet the game never runs out of surprises or fun. I would highly recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of the dungeon crawler genre, pixelated graphics, or adventure games in general.

P.S. : you can not jump in this game, space is just another attack key. I learned this the hard way, with the help of a gap, ledge, and pool of lava.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Pretty decent game. It still needs work and I honestly think you should hold out for a release because it's been four months since the last word on development and honestly this game is barely worth $8 in it's current state. It's a pretty engaging game if dungeon crawls are your thing. It's got all the stuff that makes a dungeon crawler wonderful.

I enjoyed it a lot but I have a couple gripes:

First, this game is like all the other roguelike-likes. It has randomly generated levels and some light RPG mechanics and that's it for likenesses. I would love to have a roguelike-like that doesn't distance itself so heavily from roguelike mechanics, but what can you do.

Second, the difficulty spikes through the ceiling at the end. The game's really easy for something that bills itself as a roguelike game, up until the very end. It's really frustrating to work your way through the game for an hour or two only to hit an unbeatable ending that throws the cheapest difficulty it can at you: flooding the rooms with spawns of endgame enemies at a rate of ~1/sec(that's an honest estimation, not an exaggeration). I'm all for reasonable progression of difficulty, and this ain't it.

Overall, I kinda-sorta recommend this game. It definitely needs work, but I think you'll find some enjoyment out of it in its current state. Whether that enjoyment is worth $8 is debatable. I would personally suggest you wait for more work to be done on it before buying.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Delver looked good. I heard a good review and it was on sale so I checked it out. I beat the game in 74 minutes. After learning some basic strategies, enemies became super predictable and completely unthreatening. At no point was there any fear or tension. I killed the boss without even realizing his significance. With no enemy scaling, leveling health and decking myself out in good armor made me essentially unkillable. Even barring that, the endgame whoopsie do of having to run back through the entire level refilled with monsters was a cakewalk. You could run circles around them and not get hit. On top of that, the twist ending bored me. There was no presentation to it, no aplomb, no reason to care about it.

I have no reason to come back to this game. I have seemingly seen all there is to see in it. I enjoyed my time delving, but have been given no reason to ever come back to it. There is no point to this game being a roguelike, which was the entire reason I wanted to play it in the first place. Even if there is some second and third layer of fun I could come back to, it's not evident. Character progression is not saved. There is no reward for beating the game.

I had fun. I was expecting so much more. The money per time enjoyed ratio is higher than a longer theatrical release. That's not what I've come to expect out of games.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a very promising game judging on what I've just played. I started playing two hours ago and I haven't stopped. I even got my sister to play it. I appreciate the graphics as it's become its own style.  The music is fitting and very importantly not annoying since I will be hearing the same tunes for a while. The combat is satisfying since enemies literally just obliterate when dying (and not to mention how bad I feel for the bats when they squeak). Some of the weapons and skills could use a description and perhaps there can be more interaction with the environment such as breakable boxes rather than unbreakable ones. A lot of this is just fine tuning and my opinion, though.
There isn't much to spoil in this game as all of it will unravel as you start playing. It was worth my 8 dollars for sure.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nA very neat little game, and a very great roguelike for people who like those. Its combat and item systems are pretty well made and the difficulty progresses fairly as you progress. Since this game is in early access, there are obviously going to be new things added soon most likely, and the game is made in a way where it is very open to new things, which is what I really enjoy about it. Even though death means you start all over, you don't have to always start completely from scratch, as you keep your collected gold and can buy powerful items from the start if you wish to do so, which is another thing real enjoyable about this game. Overall, my early access rating would have to be 9/10. If you really enjoy roguelike games, this game is an amazing approach to it, and any fans of the genre would definitly enjoy this game.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nDelver is an addicting, first-person, dungeon crawler with procedurally generated dungeons. It is still of course unfinished, so there are bugs to fixed and new things to be added, but it is still very satisfying. However, it doesn't really bring much new to the table. It's still a beautiful game in both sound, graphics, and gameplay, but it's not quite a masterpiece. It's like one of Picasso's early paintings. It's still great, but not like his later paintings which truly defined him. Nonetheless, it is still tons of fun to play, and keeps on bringing you back again and again, even after you've beaten the game. Despite not being completely inventive, it still is a lovely game, and even for $7.99, considering that it is still is in early access, i highly reccomend it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Your crave for adventure starts here! Bleed out of your eyes as you fight through poison zombies, magic skeletons, crazy ladies which are impossible to avoid, and bats.. SO MANY BATS!!! Besides all the rage that will consume your soul as you delve deeper and deeper to the earths god damn core, you will have the time of your life! Fly through the first 2 floors as you throw books at your enemies, level up damage and health constantly, and eat raw meat with ease! Break crates that are usualy filled with nothing, and find more wands than you could ever possibly need!

In all honusty I find this game insanely addictive, and will keep you wanting more. The game play is fantastic, and the artwork is beautiful. Secret areas and doors will keep you occupied, and traps that block your way will keep you on your toes. Feel a sense of relief when you find the entrance to the next floor, and nearly ♥♥♥♥ your pants as you almost fall to your demise! This is a super fun game, and I would replay it if even the slightest bit of content was added.

I give this game a 9/10, and here is it's draw backs:

-The boss fight wasn't as intense or memorable as I would have liked it to be

-There wasn't much of an ending after the boss fight (Although I kind of expected that)

-Very few bugs

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Picked up Delver during the Steam Sale. Definitely worth the $3 it cost.

I wouldn't call it '3d' in more than a limited sense, it feels a lot more like Doom's 2.5d- 3d environments, sprite monsters, etc. Still, it's one save file you can't back up and one life in a randomly generated roguelike. It actually makes for a pretty cool story:

I started off in a little camp with a couple of shopkeepers and the obligatory guest appearance of Old Man Exposition, who explained that there was a MacGuffin at the bottom of yonder dungeon. He also seemed troubled that people kept going in but never coming out. More on that later.

So I notice I have no gold, yet everything the shopkeepers sell costs gold. Okay, fine, we'll come sell some crap later. I head down the ramp, at which point the music changes to a far darker and more foreboding track. It was more apt than I realized, but I ignored it as I clicked on the door.

Ten minutes later and I'm about halfway through the first floor of the dungeon, packing my inventory with goodies to sell. You get a pretty generous inventory, and I was crammed to the gills with extra armor and weapons to unload. A quick glance at my map and I headed for the exit. Reached the door... and it's locked. The key is the MacGuffin. ♥♥♥♥.

I do a quick Google search and lo and behold, there is no selling of items to shops- any gear other than the best stuff you've got is essentially dead weight. I tossed half my inventory on the spot and continued downwards, making it three levels before getting vaporized in a headlong hasted charge on a Beholder. Thus ended Game One.

A couple presses of the Return key later and I find myself back in the camp. My inventory looks a little different- a different starting wand, a gold potion instead of a red one (the potions randomize their effects every game and you have to find out which is which by drinking them- and one just happens to be poison; the game really does hate you). And now I find out why there's shopkeepers: My gold carries over between runs, so previous me can give current me a head start with some gear and a stat point or two. As I got ready and drank my starter potion to find out what it was (arcane shield this time), I remembered the old man's words:

There's a lot of people going in
date: but nobody ever comes out."\n\nOver the next two hours I went in several times
recommended: and never came back out. Death happens a lot in this game- and usually right when you start to get cocky. I began learning to glance at my health bar every few seconds
hoursPlayed: more if I was in combat. Keeping myself in top shape was a priority- every level had its own special combination of ranged and melee mobs

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I beat this game on my very first try in under two hours, and I've just realized that that means I can get a refund for it, which I'm now sure to do. For what this game is, it looks and feels very, very nice. The pixel art, engine, and polish on this game are all very well done, and the beginning of the game left a pretty good taste in my mouth (which may be more than some people say for my game, Barony). However, this game simply has no depth to it. The music is very limited and loops constantly, so even though it sounds nice at first it gets tiring quickly. There are no skill trees, there is no diversity in each playthrough, and the mechanical variety of the game is just so low -- it's hard to describe, but gameplay-wise, there's no MEAT to this game.

I was not aware that this game even existed when I made my own first-person roguelike"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ok, so let me be perfectly blunt here. I have played little more than an hour of this game so far, but I can already sum up everything I have to say about Delver in one word: Potential.
Delver is a fresh, unique take on the rogue-like games that have been pouring in recently from many indie developers from all over the world. It takes on many thematic rogue-like elements: It's challenging, randomly generated, and as fun as a bag full of rabid chipmunks dumped into an elementary school.
I'm not saying this game is without its issues, but it's still in its early access phase, and must be taken with a grain of salt. Considering this fact, Delver is chocked full of endless potential. Its first-person perspective and highly pixelated environment and graphics allow this game far more room to breathe then one would expect at first glance. Even in its early phases, the amount of different consumable items and pieces of unique equipment are quite impressive, and the level-up system that resets after every miserable failure allows a very immersive RPG-like quality to the game. You're able to play differently every single run. Want to focus on high armor and melee combat? Go right ahead! Feel like going for a more mobile, long-range bow combatant? Be my guest! Or maybe you just want to pump all of your points into magic and blow the CRAP out of every enemy in sight with one of the many different elemental weapons in the game. Why wouldn't you?!
It is this amount of flexibility within a game that is comprised of so little options as of right now that makes me positive that there's no where to go but up from here for Delver. So many environments yet to be created; so many monsters yet rendered in that simplistic-yet-beautiful art style; many more items, potions, and pieces of armor yet to be looted off of bandit corpses or found in the dank corner of a cave! Heck, there is even a large part of the Delver community that claims this game has everything it needs to move on to an online co-op mode! Who knows?
All I can say is, that even after only an hour of gameplay, I can already close my eyes and imagine what can be done with a game this inventive, this creative, this simple, and this ambitious! If you haven't taken a peek at Delver yet, I suggest very highly, for the love of yourself AND your rabies-free elementary schoolers that you do. This game is nothing but raw potential and ingenuity, and I KNOW you don't want to miss out on it! That being said:
This is the Captain, Signing Out.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Delver is a roguelike where you have to enter a dungeon randomly generate. The game is still in early access but I think it has potential. Unfortunately, it is very short ; you finish the dungeon in about 1 hour. The bestiary, weapons and the list of items are not very comprehensive. Fortunately, there are mods that add more diversity to the game. The soundtrack is very good and the retro style is great and there are texture pack if you want. The game has a level editor too.

Finally, I would say that this game is not too worth it if you expect to spend long hours. But this game has potential, continues to be updates by the developer and for 7€ is cheap.

English version
(Wersja polska poniżej)

This charming little piece of dungeon crawling may have nothing truely unique to offer, but besides that, it's simple,solid and stylish. And it provides that eerie feeling I remember from exploring the caves in the Minecraft.

The combat is simple, yet engaging. There is a variety of melee,  ranged and magical weapons available and balancing quick, strong and ranged attacks is the key to survival.

The graphics of this game are really appealing. While pixelated, they perfectly fit together to create a consistent minecrawl" experience. Special mention goes to the utterly hilarious
date: 80-90s anime styled facial expressions the human enemies make when hit. Music is also likable and moody.\n\nWhat I didn’t really enjoy is the character leveling system.  While it is traditionally experience based
recommended: on every level the player is given 3 choices on what to upgrade. The problem is that there are more than three stats and thus sometimes there is no option to improve the desired characteristic and the  progress gets a bit random. Furthermore

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A Recipe for Nostaglic and Indie Goodness
Mix The Legend of Zelda" with "Shadowgate" together and sift "Dragon Warrior" through the top and fold it over in a large mixing bowl of condensed "Doom". Put the contents in a pan buttered with "Dungeons of Dagorath" and into the oven pre-heated at 16-bit graphics and what do you know? You get THIS delicous nostalgic and exciting gem called "Delver".

I just LOVE retro games
date: even though I didn't exist in the 80's or even the 90's. And you don't see tweens who would rather play Centipede than Call of Duty enough these days. (Maybe only where I live.) Anyways
recommended: the simplistic fun of those games just tugs at my heartstring. Everything from Coleco-vision to the Nintendo 64 I love. (And I don't think E.T. for the Atari 2600 is that bad either.) Well
hoursPlayed: I shouldn't say EVERY GAME or EVERY SYSTEM. (shudders at the thought of the Philips CD-i) But
voteText: I bet you get the picture. I was looking in the Google Play store on my tablet
helpfulPercent: searching "What other users installed" for Minecraft Pocket Edition. I scrolled WAY down until my eyes caught the glimpse of a simple 8-bit figure wearing a green shirt and holding a stick. I decided to check it out. Now what I DON'T like is a classic game ripoff. But I can't find a game in the back of my head that is almost exactly the same as the game Delver. So
votesTotal: hoping my money didn't go to waste. The description of the game is definatly true to its word
commentsCount: there were a couple bugs in the game
column16: and the controls were kind of awkward
column20: the entire game. A while after that
column21: I got Steam. When I discovered Delver was also on Steam
column22: I couldn't be more excited. The controls were MUCH better than the version I had on my tablet. I just couldn't wait for the next updates.\n\nWell
column23: that's my story how I found Delver
column25: there are also reasons I LOVE to play Delver.\n\nI've read some of the negative reviews on Steam
column26: some of them complain that there is little story to this game. I could care less about a story than those guys. I would rather just play the game and explore a dangerous dungeon in which I would probably die a horrible death in order to get a useless item because "what the heck
column27:
than sit through endless cutscenes or do a lot of reading. The leveling up system is both very simplistic, but very effective and game-changing at the same time. The music is AWESOME! I could listen to the game's tracks all day. Getting to the Orb, the music is somewhat calm but suspensful and adventurous at the same time. When you go back to the surface, though, the music immediatly switches to all out frightening and suspensful, raising your stress meter. The abundant variety of weapons, armor, wands and the ability to hold something on your left hand is remarkable and you can't help but to be very stingy about the items you have in your inventory. You never know what the potions would do in each game, and which ones to drink or not. But as long as you know which potion is which in the earliest floors, The relevently small inventory space show that there is not a lot to spare and you need to be very conservative, in which I like. The easier reach to the Orb will make you feel that this game is to easy and you become cocky. But once you get the Orb, you realize that Delver's adventure is not yet over. You still need to escape to the surface. That's when all heck breaks lose. Enemies start to respawn, not to metion those annoying skeleton mages whose magic cooldown seems like a half a second. The difficulty gets much harder than ever before, and you have a very long way to go before you get to the top. The entire thrill and the adventure of the game captures my heart.

There are not many things for me to wish anymore about this game. Although, a few things doesn't mean anything at all, despite how amazing I believe this game is. Every once in a blue moon, the rest of the dungeon becomes impossible to progress and continue, which is very dissapointing the moment you discover it. On your journey to the Yithidian Orb, I noticed that enemies don't respawn. I would like the developers to add respawning to the first half of the game to make it a little harder, but not too hard though. When you get to the boss, I would like the boss fight to be nessecary to get the Orb. Plus, the boss fight is insignificant and easy. All you need wolf down an arcane and iron skin potion and you practically won the fight. I've also noticed a pattern that some of the rooms are exactly the same in other runs, and that more variety of rooms and maps should be added. Bigger and more floors would be nice, too. Other than that, I have no other complaints.

I can't wait when Delver is going to be off Beta stage. I hope more people will come and play this wonderful game. Delver team, don't stop on improving the game. Please know that this game has HUGE potential and that there are fans, eager to play the game.

Well, that's all I have to say. Aldisimoo, OUT!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Game has some serious balance issues. Enemies that jump at you can jump and hit you well before they're in your weapon range. Sometimes they land on top of you where you can't hit them but they can hit you. I've seen bats fly up through the ceiling where you can't hit them, only to fly down out of the ceiling to hit you. Despite the fact that the game isn't too difficult it just feels like it can have many cheap hit moments. I'd rather have a hard game that felt fair.

Arrows are messed up. If you shoot an arrow then pick it up again it no longer stacks in the same stack. Arrows bought in the store don't stack in the same stack. It's like what the heck were they thinking?

No I have not put a whole lot of time into this game. That's because there's not much to the game right now. It has around 10 levels to explore.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Besides the typical trends of -INDIE- -ROGUELIKE- -PIXEL GRAPHICS- that games these days try and cash in on, this game is actually pretty fun. It felt reminiscent of Daggerfall's dungeons or early dungeon crawling games of the 90s except with modern controls and pacing. This isn't a turn based roguelike, which is hilarious refreshing in what is one of my favourite genres now bloated with similar games trying to cater to people who only care about what I said above  (memes indie 16-bit roguelikevmetrovai- blah blah blah etc etc).

The aesthetics are crisp and colorful and some weapons feel weighty and it's very satisfying knocking out monsters or pesky mages into blood pudding. Also traps in the dungeons effect the bad dudes and I spent more than I'd like to admit trailing bandits into a spike pit.

When you slap people's nuts a little too hard but not enough to put them down, they'll run off and try and flank/sneak up on you, which is cool.

I put all my stats into defence and attack and wore big platemail armor. This worked pretty well until a bunch of spooky liches tore me a new one with magic while I was huffed and puffed trying to get away.

Only downer is it's an early access game and could use some content or fleshing out. I made it down 7th or so floor before being lich target practice (apparently this is the last floor?).

This game is under 10$ CDN, how can you say NO to this.

I also smashed a bandit with a sword in the face with a hammer and it made a sound like he pooped himself while he flew off a cliff into lava from the blow.

I give it 6 green potions out of cheese piece.

YUM.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It can be frustrating the fist few tries until you manage to get a setup that drops some decent gear on you and gets you moving, but it's a heck of a fun little RPG once you reach that point and really start making progress through a dungeon.

The Minecraft-like graphics also help give it a feel that's somewhere at a happy compromise between retro and modern.

My only grip is that is DOES have some balancing issues that cause it to occasionally generate a dungeon that kills you right off the bat due to lack of equiptment (the starting dagger is horrid because it's range is so short) and to many tough enemies clogged into one early area.

I got it in the Rouge-Like Humble Bundle, but I see it's only $8 on here so I'd say it's definatly worth it if you're into that sort of thing because being a fully realized 2.5D, first person dungeon crawler seems to be a bit of a rarity in this genre that tends to favor retro-style top-down or side-scrolling RPGs.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Early Access Review
I'll start off by saying that this game has a lot of replay value, however it's a little on the short side and finishing the game isn't all that hard. One thing that I need to point out is just how beautiful this game is. The shape of the land isn't made of cubes like what you'll find in Minecraft, but it's all shaped to really make a dungeon, cave, or sewer scene come to life. The only thing that is cubey are the textures on the landscape.

The combat is simple but it isn't boring. You can choose to use a dagger, sword, longsword, club, bow, or one of the many magic wands that do different things. Like a true RPG, as you play you'll level up, you can power up stats (health, speed, etc..), and you will also find higher level armor, weapons, and enemies.

This is the perfect game for anyone looking for a rogue-like RPG dungeon crawler.
Delver is worth the CDN$8.79 price. It has earned all of it's positive reviews.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

PROS:
-Dive-on-in style of play, start the game, jump in and try your luck!
-Permadeath makes the game feel more enthralling until the inevitable loss of a character you like/got far with.
-Lovely pixelated art style.
-Britty guud atmosphere, and the level designs are varied, too!
-Combat feels good, and kills gitcha PUMPED.
-Exploration is satifying.
-Loot is restricted to items you can use, no shop/merchant goo-goo-goo bull-♥♥♥♥.
-Randomly generated dungeons keep each play session fresher than the average bear.

CONS:
-Pretty much abandoned, although the devs beg to differ on their twitter (but I'm not making a twitter to find out lol ♥♥♥♥ twitter).
-Few bugs here and there, nothing really game-breaking that I've run into thus far.
-Is still in beta stage after being released nearly three years ago for EA (Early Access) purchase.
-Last update was September 21st, 2015. Quickly approaching the year mark since it was updated.

All in all, I'll gladly change this review to a recommendation as soon as another update comes along/the devs show they care/it comes out as a full release. Really fun FPS roguelike, but unless you can comfortably toss $7.99 away on a game that may or may not be finished, I'd recommend waiting for a sale or it's full release.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In response to the recent crap about this game being abandoned:

Now I have been hearing a lot of crap about how this game has been abandoned and how you “Should not buy it until its finished.” Screw those guys. They have NOT played it enough. I mean the guys have not even played 5 hours. So yes this game has not been updated since 9/20/2015, but if you take a honest look at what they have here its a near complete game. The only update it may need are a couple of bug fixes to things not even game breaking. I mean its not like cube world where there is nothing and might be abandoned. Cube world is boring and abandoned. This game is fun and might be abandoned. This game still has new things to throw at me and I have played 42 hours so far and thinking I've seen everything but then I made a new play through and boom I've seen a dungeon layout that I've never seen before. I even saw some treasure rooms and I'm like “Since when did delver have treasure rooms?” Put this game on your wish list and buy it when its on sale. This game is worth it.

Now time to my actual review

This game is a throwback to how games used to be. Before story was added. Before you needed to know enough statistics you might as well get a fricken degree in the stuff. I thinking of YOU pokemon, I love you but my gosh your competitive play is just full of maths. Literally you wake up at a camp and need talk to some guys and walk into a door and boom your in the game. Your goal? Get to the end of the dungeon, grab the orb and get back to the start. Sounds easy right? Hah! Nope! As soon as you grab the orb, the quiet peacefull dungeon run you had on the way down, which I must say isn't very hard but just engaging enough to keep playing but at the same time punishes your mistakes, is now a absolute hell hole where you just want to survive the trek up. I make sounds of terror that I have never made before on my way up. If your an angry person, this game may not be for you just for this part. My gosh I love it. As soon as you grab the orb you see why this game is called rouge like.

I rate this game 10/10 yes I really do, I don't care if its abandoned or not this is a good game.
If you don't want to buy it now put it on your wish list and remember it exists because you have no excuse to not buy this game when its on sale. This is one of the best Indie games I've played and deserves more credit.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It looked great when I saw it on sale, so I picked Delver up. There are definitely a lot of good things going on with this game, and it has the potential to scale into something truly massive and amazing over time. I haven't tried the custom mod tools yet, though I'm hoping they provide options to greatly increase the depth of content available.

After finally playing through it in its current state, I feel like I missed something - or the game is missing something - because it took me all of 1.6 hours to learn the game and complete it (even the run back) and the lack of a meaningful ending left it feeling like a hollow victory.

I'd really love to talk with the developer and community together sometime to explore the current state of the game, and determine ways in which Delver could be made more amazing and worthwhile for everyone to buy and play. I was hoping for something that scales more like Diablo, 20+ floors and constantly rotating out gear for better stuff throughout the game, multiple classes with variations, well-defined boss enemies, or just to have truly everything randomized and have every experience be a new adventure. Right now the potions and dungeon layout are the only things which change, the variety of loot is rather static, and I come in exactly the same every time.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I figured I'd say my piece.
I love this game, I haven't played that long, but whenever I can't think of absolutely anything to do I always somehow end up playing this game. It has plenty of good points, and some not so great ones.

The movement and combat is really satisfying, and brings me back to my childhod, when I'd play Doom with my dad. It's nice to see a Rogue Like that has a little bit of skill to it as well as the random aspect, although RNG can still sometimes kill you.

I've never made it past the area after the sewers, crypt maybe? I can't remember what it's called. So I don't know how much end game content there is to this game. As it stands right now, it feels a little short, and a little shallow, but also not bad or unsatisfying. If this looks like a game that would appeal to you, it probably will.

I give it a solid 7.5 out of 10.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Somewhat First Impressions:

Been following since early alpha.
Great little game with a lot of promise. And I'm hoping it lives up to it.
Simple but fun first person roguelike with a distinct Ultima Underworld feel.
Comes with an easy to use map editor and the ability to mod in community-made maps. This will hopefully increase the longevity of the game.

As of this writing there hasn't been an update in a few months. But prior to that, the updates were great and always adding in new features. The switch to a proper artist was probably the best decision the developer made. I hope to see the game expand with more features and gameplay options in the future.

Verdict: Looks promising but maybe wait to see how it turns out. As of right now it is only good for a few hours of entertainment, after which you'll get bored.

Early Access Review

An interesting and somewhat fascinating first person dungeon crawler marred by boring and repetitive dungeons and a simplicity that, while it makes the game easier to get into and lowers the price of admission, ultimately makes the replayability of the game low. The drop system needs reworking, as well. I've had games where I've gotten all kinds of spectacular gear drops throughout my run, and others where I was struggling to get fully equipped by the third floor.

If you can get it cheaper than the asking price - say, about around $2.99 or so - then it's totally worth it. Otherwise, you're not missing much here.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

EDIT: I decided to come back to this to see what changes have been made, and guess what? Despite some changes that were for the better, the game still hasn't managed to get better in terms of gameplay. The game still feels like a bare bones action dungeon crawler RPG with rogue-like elements thrown in. Though it is very nice that you now have more use for your weapons than just killing enemies (for example, breaking down a door with your mace or breaking a crate in order to search for loot), that skill jars now cost more and that there is more variation with the music, the game still has not advanced enough for me to say that the game is going somewhere. In fact, I think the game actually took some steps back, especially with its new leveling system. The new leveling system works like this: each time you level up, you are allowed to put one point into one of three randomly chosen stats. This is a problem because it doesn't give the player a choice on what kind of build they actually want to have, which defeats the purpose of being able to put stat points into whichever stats you want in the first place. Now, once again, one might bring up the skill jars, but I should not have to grind money, die a couple of times, and then buy all these jars just to get the build I want to have, especially in a dull game like this. Speaking of dull, the game is still a dull hack and slasher RPG with enemies who are not very competent at catching up with you. Combat is still virtually the same, scroll wheels are still not an option, the game still lacks custimization features, etc. All in all, the game may have added some neat things, but it isn't enough to save the game. I would still not recommend picking this game up, at least for now, that is.

ORIGINAL POST: Now that the October Patch is out and now that I've played some more of it, I will give my current thoughts on Delver. The good news is that the developer has revamped the RPG system. The bad news is that I still don't see it being a good game any time soon. My reasons? Lets start with the gameplay.

The gameplay of Delver may have been expanded upon when it comes to the RPG system, but the gameplay still pretty much sucks ♥♥♥. This time, the game has a shop and gold, and it saves your gold count when you die so that you can use that gold at the shop before entering the dungeon, which sounds nice, but can be used to break the game. How? By saving a ♥♥♥♥ ton of money (lets say about a little over a thousand gold) through multiple playthroughs and using that money to buy jars of skill, a type of item that sells for 20 gold and levels you up upon use, you can easilly kill the difficulty. Some may argue to not use them, seeing as they are optional, but they are in the game, and I feel that they shouldn't be that easy to get, seeing as this game is supossed to be a difficult action rogue-like RPG. In terms of combat, I think it's actually clunkier than the last time I played it, especially when it comes to the hit detection. There were moments in the game where I was hitting enemies, but the hit didn't register for any good particular reason. This was especially common with magic attacks. Speaking of magic, for some reasons, magic weapons seem to be quite overpowered, killing a lot of enemies in one hit. The game also has moments of being unbalanced, as I've had moments on the first floor where I got killed in one hit. The developer still hasn't added the ability to use the scroll wheel, which is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, considering how many other First-Person RPGs make use of the scroll wheel to change weapons and items. The game also still likes to spawn very powerful equipment in early stages, though not as often as it did when I last played it, so that's a plus. In the end, however, the bad still outweighs the good, and Delver still feels like a generic Action-RPG with nothing going for it.

Presentation wise, the game has made drastic changes with its visuals, and although I'm not too fond of these new visuals, they are ♥♥♥♥ tons better than the graphics that Delver used to have (seriously, those graphics were an eye sore). Music wise, Delver still has that god awful dungeon music, although the update added a new tune that is more pleasant to the ears to fit the shop camp that is outside the dungeon. An improvement in these areas, but they could still be better.

And now, the performance. I don't know about anyone elses experience, but I found that the game is glitchier then when I last played it. Yeah, not a good thing at all. I had one moment in the game where I found a bow that was floating midair, and I couldn't take it for some reason. I even have the image to prove it. The game also loves to close on its own, as the game closed on me while I was in the dungeon. Also, the game is still unoptimized as ♥♥♥♥.

Despite its improvements, the game is still rather ♥♥♥♥♥♥, and I still think that people should avoid this game at this point in time.

So I just played and finished my very first game of this. And I have to say it's really really fun, even at such an early point in development. It was incredibly tense when I was fighting my way through the enemies in an attempt to reach the surface, using what small resources I had left after getting to the bottom of the dungeon.
And the gameplay is just what I want from this kind of Roguelike, you have to learn everything and aren't spoonfed information, you'll have no idea what a Potion does until you drink it, which is great, you can be on very low health and be in the situation of If I drink this potion will it heal me
date: or kill me".\nLearning how attacks interact with each other is fun as well
recommended: I used a potion on a Pressure Plate and it exploded
hoursPlayed: which led me into learning that hitting a potion on the floor turns it into a bomb
voteText: very useful considering how far you can throw items. Or that if your Magic Attack hits an Enemies Magic Attack
helpfulPercent: it will explode both and deal AoE damage. The only thing I never actually figured out was what the Agility stat did.\nThe graphics
votesTotal: fit the style and genre of the game perfectly because in a Roguelike you don't want to be overloaded with details you want everything to be fairly simple
commentsCount: which is what this game achieves. While the graphics aren't realistic
column16: they present a great atmosphere for the game and really help with immersion.\nThe Music is also good
column17: it just quitely sits in the background and blends well with the ambient sounds
column18:
not drowning out anything important such as the movement or chatter of enemies.

Things I would like to see in the future of this game are:
- More varied qualities to accessories
column19: weapons and armour. Like qualities that affect gameplay in a more meaniingful way than just stat changes. Depending how it would influence how the game plays.\n- Perhaps a way to make potions
column20: using ingredients that you don't know what they do until you use them.\n- Perhaps a way of recharging wands
column21: as I tended to end up carrying 6 wands around and throwing them away once one ran out. That would mean making wands a bit rarer though.\n- Some ways to specialise as a character
column22:
maybe a class system that have different starting stats and items?
- And maybe... mod support if possible? When the game is finished of course.

Overall though
column23: even lacking some of the things I would like
column24: this game is incredibly fun and I will probably continue to play it for a while

Early Access Review

Bought this for sale 66% off at $2.50ish during a steam sale. I think this was money well spent for the hour or so of enjoyment I got out of the game. Even buying it at full price, it would have paid for itself.

The combat is pretty basic but it works well for the slow paced combat. The visuals are very reminiscent of Minecraft along with all the controls. The inventory system works well for allowing you to collect loot along your trip down the dungeon and the randomized potions give a little risk to using them each time you restart, which is frustrating but in a good way.

As for faults, the level/stat system is a little broken as you only need to put points into health for the first five levels and defense the rest to become relatively hard to kill. Ranged combat versus flying enemies, which is when it's needed, is a fools game unless you're using a lightning wand (almost hit scan), as projectiles have travel time and flying enemies juke around way too much to predict their movements. I just found myself running up under them and stabbing upward for a sure hit.

Finally, while I died the first time down the dungeon due to trying to figure out the system, I beat the game on the second try. I received a slash screen of text and then the game treated me like I had died. I'm pretty much not going down a third time until there are further updates, but as I said at the start, I got my money's worth already and I recommend a purchase, especially if it's on sale again.

TL;DR - It's an enjoyable game but has it's issues. Worth a buy, especially if it's on sale.

Could have been fun to have local or online co-op but at the same time working alone makes the game feel so creepy at times even with it's graphics right out of a Super Nintendo!

It took only a few minutes for me to fall in love with this game.  There is a quality to it that is somewhat difficult to put your finger on at first, but I would be describe the environment as being almost perfect.

While this game is a roguelike (yes, yes someone is always going to complain about how this isn't a pure roguelike) when I first loaded the game I felt flashes of playing the Secret of Mana for the first time.  A combination of the music, the art, the very simple UI, and carefully timed, if simple, combat hit me right in the nostalgia.

Currently it is in beta, and there is much content I have yet to explore, but there is only one shortcoming I see so far.  I want multiplayer.  I don't care what it takes, quadruple the difficulty per person, but I would absolutely love to have multiplayer.  I'll pay for multiplayer DLC, whatevs.

I highly recommend this game.

Early Access Review

Having played this game a long time ago, I was unimpressed. Since then there has been a significant graphical update (and a sale) which pushed me to buy it, and I do not regret it. Keep in mind, though that this is an early game, so there are still some unimplemented 'core' features.

+ A real-time roguelike with engaging first-person combat. Very enjoyable combat.
+ I do like that the levels have their own styles, rather than being the same shape with different art.
+ The stats have a very definite impact on your gameplay.

- I don't think there's enough variety in the random level generation to make it worth playing through more than once. Especially the damned sewer levels.

- I don't think Delver (right now) has much replay value. I found just maxxing your Health to the exclusion of all other stats is really the most effective strategy. I did that, beat the boss, and practically waltzed back up to the surface, orb in hand, without a scratch. What did I have to show for it? Nothing except money. Exactly the same thing I would have had if I died to the end boss.

- I never bought anything from the shop anyway. There's plenty of free loot in the dungeon, better than what you can buy. I found no reason to collect nor spend money. Maybe shops in the dungeon would help because I often need a specific item, like a potion or wand. I'm a big fan of the wands*. Please put in more kinds of wand.

*Totally not guns.

~ What if beating the Lich unlocked lower levels?
~ What if lower levels unlocked more items from the shop/more shops?

It's a fun game, which I enjoyed more than I expected to, but it is not done yet! Very playable, but feels empty and pointless once you've beat the Lich once. I was kinda hoping for a whole new dungeon to open up, but it's early days.

For me, Delver seems to have hit the difficulty sweet spot for roguelikes. While I may die on some runs out of carelessness, I'll usually return to the surface successfully in Delver. That's something I can't say about any other Retrieve-The-Orb games.

Maybe it's because this game is a first-person action game, something that roguelikes usually aren't. I personally find it more engaging to play. Which means I'll play it more, and thus be more successful more often.

What's really amazing is that this game isn't finished, yet it is already extremely fun to play. A great example of what an Early Access game should be.
Early Access Review\n\nThis looks promising, I hope to see more!

Early Access Review

Delver, the Early Access Rogue-Like RPG.

I saw this game and it sparked my interest because it reminded me a little of Might and Magic World of Xeen. Then upon realizing it was a first person rogue-like game and not the typical side scrolling one, I had to get it.

The game looks and play beautifully, I changed the key bindings a little more to my tastes but it probably won't bother most on its default settings. On the games website you can buy a HD Sphax PureBD pack (You might recognize the name from the popular Minecraft Texture pack) for $4.90 (2.90€).  The game should be able to run on any computer than can use Steam, due to the simplistic graphics and the slider in the menu.

As far as the Rogue aspect of the game, it does it a little differently than say, Rogue Leacy. In that game, you only get the gold from each run to spend as you have to spend it all to enter the castle. But in Delver, you keep all of your gold from each run, but lose any equipment that you got. But once you buy something, you always have it, which is nice. You level up in the dungeon and have a series of classic RPG stats that you can increase, but Health should always be your number 1 priority when leveling as it was the only one that had a major difference to difficulty/gameplay. I got lucky on my longest run and found a warhammer with long reach and high damage. The wands you find will be very useful and they are the only way to get passed something that can happen in the game. Speed is probably the least useful stat in the game especially when matched against Health. I'd like to see a little more depth in the stats.

I really didn't notice any bugs that stopped my progress in the game and I could honestly see this game, in its current phase of development, packaged as a full game, I would certainly buy it again. 10/10 and good on the Devs.

Early Access Review

Incredibly hard, crazy rogue-like, with a variety of terrain, weapons, and other items. A fresh take on the rogue-like genre, being in first person. Started out as a post on tigsource, updating almost every day. Now on steam early-access, with sparse updates.

Pros:
•Of all the rogue-likes I've played, this one is probably the most achievable whilst still being difficult.
•Variety of weapons and other helpful items that you can dual wield, with an alright variety of monsters and terrain.
•A nice atmosphere, without a simple story to discover through notes on the ground.
•A hack 'n' slash, but very well done in first person mode.
•Simple, but very replayable.

Cons:
•Horrible, horrible, textures, read below for info on how to get past that.
•Somewhat disappointing boss, which can be good for those who aren't up to the challenge. Just don't get hit, which is pretty easy.
•Once you kill the boss, you have to work your way back up the 8 floors you just traveled, which can be somewhat boring.

8/10, but if you want to enjoy it, get the official texture pack that has the original textures from the game when it was on tigsource, which are far better than this crunchy-pixel crap. The texture pack is updated with every update, and has optional mods" that slightly improve generation."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A pretty casual roguelike experience. As of this post, I played it a few times and quickly made it far; only dying to either burst (Didn't get enough health or armor), or my own stupidity. It's very short, which I suppose is a good thing for a game like this. It's easy, but you still can't face-check anything until you get lucky enough with weapons, armor, and stock piles of food / potions. It does get easier as the game goes on, which is a bad and good thing.

The stronger you get, the less trouble you have and are capable of dealing with most creatures. But at the same time, before you get to that stage you struggle and have to back-peddle swing many monsters to survive. You do get a lot of wands I have noticed, which trivializes a lot of encounters; which should be their purpose. But the purpose is way too strong when you get a wand drop every other kill. And the mages almost always drop them, even if they are absolute crap -- it's a ranged weapon and you take 0 damage from back-peddling and killing the enemy.

Stats are not very clear on what they do besides Attack, Speed, and Health. It's obvious you deal more damage with Attack, move faster when you up speed, and gain more health everytime you level it up. Agility was very vague on what it did, and I still don't feel the effects. The same goes for defense and magic. They feel either too weak to actually present themselves as useful, or are just not straight forward enough.

I would recommend this game on sale. It's a decent time waster for a few hours, but it has very little to give after you play through it just a few times.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nDespite the fact it says I have played under 2 hours of Delver, I have actually played at least 12 hours of this game, if not significantly more, back when it was in an earlier state. The game is still improving and is not finished, but I can recommend it in its current state. My only issue with the game is the shop system. Currently you can buy items from it using gold you obtain from enemies. At the moment, there is an item called Skill in a Jar" that levels you up and is fairly cheap. If you get enough gold
date: you can level yourself up an absurd amount of times and become so overpowered that the game is no fun. However
recommended: as long as you avoid the shop

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nDelver is a quick session-friendly action-dungeon-crawler, with inspired and stylish visuals of the schools of old. It's fast paced, challenging and very varied due to its randomized floor layouts. If you ever get tired of the base game, there's level editing tools and the ability to swap out texture packs. A nice, fun, go-to game for when nothing in your library seems all that exciting.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nOk, this the kind of game where you start off the first time, and you die within minutes. Then you respawn in the same place, and you do a little bit better. But you still die within minutes. this part isnt very frustrating, its actually really fun. The frustrating part comes when you have  gotten the ythidian orb from the last dungeon, and have almsot escaped  (basically almost beaten the playthrough), and you are rushed by a couple of skulls and a wizard-skeleton and you die within seconds. All of yoor carefully selected gear will not help you. All of your sneaking around, painstakingly rooting through the entire dungeon was for nothing. you are dead. This will cause you to quit the game for at least 10 minutes so you can cool off, but then you will get back on and try again. In the end, its a really fun game.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nA while ago I played this game for a very short amount of time (about 20 min) and could carely make it past the first cave room. I got frustrated and put this game down only to forget about it and leave it uninstalled in my library for qutie some time until I decided to try again. This experience was much different. For those of you who don't know anything about this game, it is a dungeon crawler roguelike first person rpg with a game play that I like to relate to capture the flag. Once you enter the dungeon, you cannot leave until you recover the red orb about 7 floors down and with each level you go down (randomly generated levels of course), the enemy population and difficulty along with the number of hazards increases. Once you obtain the orb, the whole dungeon goes bat ♥♥♥♥ and you have to race to the top. So essentially you must play through each floor except the last floor twice and you will progress further with each playthrough. I cannot express how satisfying it is to obtain a new weapon or level up in a tough situation and every second of this game is worth the price. I highly recommend this to anyone who loves rpgs, dungeon crawlers, roguelike first person, and consider it a must have if you enjoy all of the above.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Delver is one of the best dungeon-crawler, first person, action-RPG, roguelike/roguelite avaiable on Steam store.

You go rogue in a dungeon looking for a gem, very straight and cliche story, once you get the gem you must get the hell out of the dungeon before the horde of monster gets you. You have a lot of ways on  how to achieve that objective, you can go melee, bows and magic wands. You lv up, get some food potions and everything.....very typical rpg elements.

The diference about Delver is that in every run you will find a different dungeon, different upgrades, different items, beside that you will find a very interesting gameplay and the possibilities of modding it...Yes mods will be avaiable, in fact there is 2 or 3 mods that you can try it out.

Very recommended for any RPG,first person, dungeon crawler fan.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nWhat I liked about this game... Hmm let me start with the graphics. This game took the cake with the pixely graphics, the look of the pixels the animation blend so well together. You wouldn't expect that with most pixel styled games, half the time the animations are stiff, but this game puts it together beautifully! Next is the action. This isn't a crazy action game, more like a stroll through a dangerous and mysterious dungeon! Yes you encounter multiple enemies and hack and slash at them, very good action content. But at some points you can just admire your surroundings. But watch out for traps! Overall this game is very replayable and enjoyable. I recommend this game to all who enjoy a good roguelike action game with beautiful pixel styled art.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I found this to be a well made and entertaining, little game. I've played through it once and look forward to seeing how the finished product will turn out.

I really like the linux support and low system requirements.

There are a couple of minor, negative points I feel like pointing out:
- For some reason, as of update 5.5, the game starts up instantly when I play it in linux mint, but it takes almost 40 seconds in windows 7 (on the same computer).
- On rare occations when I picked up some armor, it completely vanished from my inventory and the game.
- There's no steam cloud functionality (yet).

Overall, this game was a fresh and pleasant experience to me. There might not be enough content right now to warrant multiple playthroughs, but hopefully that will change in the future.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nDelver is an interesting game. It's rather basic at the moment, being early access, but for eight dollars, the amount of content and effort that the game has is really impressive, and it feels very focused in its design. I can see the reason people compare it to Ultima Underworld, since much of the game's gameplay and style are clearly very inspired by it - the first one in particular, I mean. While the combat focus is very fun and the graphical style is really appealing, I actually consider the level design and generation to be the highlight here: I don't know whether it's due to working with a 3D space or whether it's simply the sheer amount of rooms and halls and things that the team have made, but in the handful of runs I've played so far, they've all felt similar, but all memorably unique thanks to how everything is built. It's a roguelike capable of creating really cool vistas, structures and views, while also making those distinct in gameplay terms as well (the dungeon is inhabited and has lots of humans and recent structures, the caves are very jagged with lots of nooks, the sewers are a mixture of open yet linear due to multiple heights, etc), and that's something to be applauded.

First play through I made it all the way to the end. I saw the orb. But it was guarded by a baddie that had a mean and deathly look about him. So I pot shot it with a few arrows rather then risk getting walloped up close.
Bad idea; this baddie had a affinity toward magic and blasted me with something foul.
It was a spell of slowing or something but what do I know I was a warrior not a mage.

The damage was little so I figured it was time to bring out old two handed. I hefted my gilded great hammer of fire and walked right up to his ugly face and smashed it in but not before I was hit a few good times. I was alive and the baddie dead so what did I care if I was near death . . .

Well turns out this baddie was a lot harder to kill then I thought. His desecrated corps burst forth with some kind of crazy voodoo magic and a bunch of skull wraiths blasted me and I died in seconds.
10/10 would get all the way to the end of the game, die and have to start over again.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game truly is amazing. It brings a true feeling of dungeon crawling. Do not be fooled by the pixelated graphics, the game looks stunning. The combination of sprites across the areas make for gorgeous scenery. The enemy sprites are easy to identify and well made. The soundtrack gives a nice feel of adventure. The music remains noted in its glory, but does no distract you from gameplay. The items available are plentiful and well made. The combat is simple enough to adapt to quickly, but still poses some danger when performing it. The game relies heavily on exploration. Notes found in the beginning town give basic instructions to gameplay and an extremely brief lore description that strangely leaves you wanting more, despite being shorter than a paragraph. Not in a long time have I played a game like this, capable of delievering a real feeling of adventure, as well as giving satisfying emotions when discovering new loot. I would recommend this game to any dungeon crawler lover, or someone who simply enjoys a well made adventure game. The fact that I say this now and the game is only in beta truly blows my mind.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nVery good game, the combat is good. It is pretty easy for the most part on the way in, it is getting out that is the hardest part. Now it can lag a bit when you maximize the screen or fullscreen it, so warning you there. However, a good, scratch that great game overall. Can't wait till the next updates come. We definitely need different dungeons, a difficulty system, more exploration around the upper world (as well as a key that will be given to the player if he deals with a challenge of some kind to get into the other dungeons, such as a guardian, a riddle, a puzzle, something) a better variety of enemies, and a hardcore adventurer option just a few examples of some changes to make it better.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis is honestly one of the best rouge-likes ive ever played. reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nDelver, while still in developement, is a great game. The game itself is a dungeon rouge-like, but is a first person game. One could say that Delver resembles Minecraft in quite a few ways, and I don't disagree. But, it's far from another Mincraft clone. The premise of the game is simple, the difficulty is not. As of this writing, the dungeon consists of seven levels/floors, each randomly generated. One must make it to the bottom, then return topside with the treasure, with various enemies being thrown at you along the way. However, the game does become monotonous at times, just to let you know. Again, it may sound like a cake-walk to some, but it really is the opposite. And although I'm used to multitudes of horror films, I jump every once and a while as a turn a corner. Recommended.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI beat the game in about 2 hours. It was somewhat interesting, but rather shallow and not very difficult. The player goes down a few floors of a dungeon and then picks up an orb that's guarded by a rather unintimidating boss (I had no idea I had killed him). After you grab the orb, you make your way back to the entrance, which you can basically just rush using a hammer. Bow and arrows are extremely buggy, bouncing all over the place and phasing in and out of reality. While it's an interesting set of ideas, it's extremely slim on content and I feel like I saw the majority of it in two hours, as layouts didn't really seem to change much between my three attempts at getting the orb. I don't think I've ever beat a rougelike in three tries before. I think my opinion on the game would change if they vastly expanded on it, but it looks like it's been in this sort of shape for a while according to the forums.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Delver is a roguelike that is visually similar to all those loveable first person games with billions of sprites (Minecraft, Doom, Wolfenstein etc).
As far as gameplay goes, it's a dungeon crawler where you pick up loot and put on the best stuff so that you can KILL MORE MOBS! Aside from that, there is nothing terribly exciting about this game. Combat is boring, there is nothing innovative, and there is nothing really driving me to keep playing. It's not a great roguelike, it's not a great RPG, it's not a great first person shooter/fighter.
10 minutes of playtime will show you everything there is to know. Don't bother getting Delver.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Delver is half nostalgia bomb, and half modern fun.
It reminds me of Ultima while being hilariously colourful, with cheerful music. It's a Tiny game MB wise, but is packed with nothing but fun. At the same time though, it's horribly difficult for newer players. It doesn't let you save and continue, and the only thing that seems to transfer when you die is gold. Not an issue at all, as the game is very addictive, and you just want to try one more time.

http://youtu.be/Wr5wkOjHkcw

The graphics, are extremely lovely. I've always liked pixel art, and blending with the lovely music it really creates a lovely atmosphere.
It's rather hard to think that the game is in early access. It plays so much better than the majority of early access games.
It's so easy to recommend this to people that just want a darn fun first person roguelike dungeon crawler.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is impressive, so far.

Do you like challenge? Delver has it. It's deceptively simple; three equipment selections with apparently-linear upgrading; you only choose whether to equip heavier armor at a loss of speed. Amulets and rings? Straightforward. Weapons? Same deal, though they can be enchanted for bonus elemental damage. All in all it seems like the sort of game you can fully-understand in 30 minutes or less.

And then, on your second or third play(or fourth or fifth), you get far enough. And you realize there's a *purpose* behind what you're doing. Me, I thought you just got to wander, fight things, find gear, and satisfy that itch to hoard, but there's more! And if you thought it was hard going deeper and deeper.... just wait for the trek back up. But that's all I'll say, as I don't want to spoil anything.

Delver is already well-worth the $7.99 it's currently selling for. The visuals are simple and remind me of Minecraft(despite not actually adhering to the same visual format at all), the sprite style is deceptively innocent, colors are vibrant and the lighting is very complimentary to the atmosphere. If you're like me, you'll find yourself creeping, ears sharp. What was that noise? Where did it come from, exactly? What made it??

Like I said, it's worth the small price tag, and that's when you know an Early Access game deserves to be Early Access. This isn't a case of well
date: it's probably gonna turn into something great given time!" at all. Delver is great
recommended: and if you want to pick it up now and get your money's worth early-on
hoursPlayed: then you'll already have it as it continues to grow bigger and better. Personally
voteText: I think I made the right choice hands-down."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A lot was promised in the Steam version and for a while, the dev kept in close contact with his fans.  Unfortunately, a lot of that communication has ceased, and I'm not really sure what Delver is supposed to be now.  It was OK while it was still clunky and buggy, but now, to me this game is mostly anti-fun.  Take whatever you expected from a first-person hardcore roguelike, throw in graphics that are extremely difficult to appreciate on larger screens (2K and higher) and obfuscate everything with a fiddly RPG system that seems to be taken out of games like Bloodwych or Eye of the Beholder but without any lore or explanation along the ride.

Another coulda been good" until the "money dried up" cliché."
