reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThough I did enjoy the game, it can be beaten in under 4 hours and the replay value is somewhat disappointing.   I can't recommend this game for over $5 mainly because of its lack of content.  Level-up's are decently-timed, but stat increases often mean nothing (dumping points into Health = always winning).  The game needs to be much longer, and stat increases need to have a much larger impact on the game and its enemies.  You often find yourself randomly finding a nice strong sword within the first few levels and watching the game become extremely easy thereafter.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Amazing graphix style, lacks content

Delver is fun little game where you delve into a dungeon fighting monsters and a boss. The thing is, it has a serious lack of content. I would only reccomend this game on sale beceause spending 8 euro's on just two hours of gametime is not worth it in my opinion (a friend of mine completed the game in 0.9 hours without rushing it).

The graphix style is amazing. I am a fan of game design in general and this has a serieus amount of potential. The main problem with the game is, as mentioned, the lack of content. As you enter the first dungeon, 'Dungeon 01' will appear on your screen. This gave me the idea there are at least 11 dungeons. Wrong. There is only 1. One single dungeon with only nine floors.

If the devs would add at least 10 more dungeons of different styles, I would change my opinion. For now, do not buy this game unless you are curious about the design and need an hour to kill.

3/10, potential but propably dead devs.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is retro-style first-person dungeon crawler. It's a very straightforward and fluid experience. The combat is fast, smooth and fun. The loot is plentiful and interesting. Everything serves a purpose and it's easy to figure out what everything does.

However, despite the straightforwardness, this is very much a rogue-like. Strong monsters are deadly accurate with attacks and are intelligent. Casters will avoid melee and attempt to kite you. Melee enemies will attempt to flank you. Your skills will be tested and it honestly feels like a match of Quake 3 at times. This is a game you can play for 10 minutes or 10 hours and still lose track of time.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nDelver is a fun little game to play if you have an hour of free time, which is around the time it takes to win the game in one sitting. reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI had to write a review, complled to do so. Lets start out with the music , its pleasnt and engages your curiosity while delving deep in the unexplored nooks and crannys of the dungeons. Graphix is fitting for this style game, a interesting mix of 2d and 3d. The dungeon environment is asthetically pleasing to the eye and done extreemly well. From the flickering of a torch to the pixilated blood splattered against the wall after a heated battle.  As a  36 year old gamer , this game takes me back to the golden era of the great RPG's , an era unfortunatly that has been long forgotten. Add some achievements and a endless dungeon mode or challenge modes and this game will be arround to stay! In beta this game is fantastic and really shows a level of creativity that few can match. I would recommend this game to anyone!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm going to preface this review with a disclaimer: This game is very unfinished and while I will recommend it, you should be willing to buy a game that may not get all of the features it promises. I bought the game on sale and I do not regret my purchase. No onto the review.

This game, while being described as an action roguelike, is not a roguelike, but a rogue-like-like. It has some roguelike elements but it's missing some of the soul and core mechanics that roguelikes are supposed to have. That doesn't mean it's a bad game, but you should consider this before buying.

The basic concept of the game is simple: Delve into the dungeon, make it to the bottom, grab the treasure and escape alive. There are enemies and traps along the way to stop you of course, and the twist of needing to escape with your life adds more difficulty and stress to an otherwise easy game. If you've played a lot of rogue-like-likes before you shouldn't find it too hard to make it to the bottom and beat the boss, but making it back should prove a lot harder.

Besides the dungeon, there is also a camp area. The camp area lets you spend your collected gold after you die to start off a run with an item, or items. These items should not be ignored and can give you a very helpful early game advantage. This is a good touch, although I wish more was done with it and the NPCs there. But remeber: The game is still in dev.

Overall I'd say Delver is a potentially deep and interesting rogue-like-like with cool ideas, and is worth sticking with for the features planned in the future. The developer has plans to add a lot more depth in items, magic, enemies, character classes and even an overworld with NPCs.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The good: Aesthetically pleasing, nice soundtrack, and smooth gameplay.

The bad: Too easy. The only stat that matters is health. If you dump all your stat points into health you'll never have to use a restorative item, ever. You'd have to put genuine effort into dying. Monster AI is boring. The gear is boring. Too many wands spawn. I'd like to see more hidden entrances, unique monsters, unique items, etc. The rollover gold is dumb. I'd rather have no gold at all or have shops inside the dungeon.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Well-designed game with a great art style and an enjoyable Roguelike romp through a dungeon. The blend of 16-bit style and first-person dungeon crawler works very well. The difficulty isn't intense and this game makes a great soothing break between sessions of more hardcore titles. Plus, Delver has none of the stink associated with Early Access titles - you'd hardly guess it's still in development while playing it.

I enjoy and would definitely recommend.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nGreat game.  Minecraft style 3-D dynamically generated roguelike. There is a good selection of weapons, armor, and monsters, and every game is different.  Some interesting mechanics, and the gameplay is solid.  I like that this game doesn't try to do too much, it knows what it wants to do and it executes perfectly.  Graphics are functional and the art style fits the game well.  Looking forward to any further updates they make, but the game is already very playable and I haven't run into any crashes.  I haven't been able to figure out how to save a game, not sure if that functionality exists yet, if not that would be my one suggestion.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Replayability: 2/5
This game may be a randomly generated rogue-like dungeon crawlers, but it gets very stale and repetitive fast. I've only played 2 hours of it while I've had the game for 2 years.

Fun: 3/5
This game is decently fun when you first start to play it, and can be quite enjoyable, but as previously stated, it get's boring fast.

Graphics: 3/5
Average, this game may be a 2D FPS game, but the artwork is very well done, However points will be deducted because of the outdated graphics.

Sound: 4/5
Great! I love the sound and music in this game, it's very captivating.

Overall score: 12/20 (60%) I do not recommend this game to anyone looking to get into the rogue-like game, it a very stale example of what this type of game can be.

Early Access Review

This game has great potential to give the player hours of fun traversing winding tunnels through the depths of the endless dungeons to find treasure and glory.  Unfortunately the games graphics are so pixely that even with everything turned all the way up it is very hard for me to discern between the different objects and makes navigating through the different passages quite irritating.  There is a few different graphic packs you can download but the only one worth getting they make you pay for which has turned me off from this game completely.

To the game developer I say make the graphics better and give people a choice between pixely and smooth lines.  For some people who have vision problems like depth perception or color blindness the over pixilazation would cause too much interference to enjoyably play this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Well done in comparison to most early access titles, Delver manages to keep a simplistic approach to gameplay yet keeps you coming back for more runs. The game allows little room for building your character as you progress, and you are left at the game's mercy when it comes to gear. As you progress deeper into the games dungeon, your play style will rely almost solely on what weapons and armor you find and your luck with the random level generator.

Still, the game is a real-time roguelike experience, and much like classic roguelikes, you will often find yourself backpedaling into doorways while trying to kite varied and numerous enemies. It's easy to catch yourself reserving all of your ranged attacks (wands rely on finite charges and bows rely on a rare stock of arrows) for dire circumstances, while searching constantly for a better melee weapon. Armor can be hit or miss, and is often a trade-off between movement speed and protection (both of which are very effective).

From death to death, your gold will carry over. The only opportunity to buy items and spells is at the beginning of each run. While the dungeon is currently very short (only seven floors), the environments are nicely varied and the randomly generated rooms keeps it feeling fresh with each attempt. It's worth the price.

Early Access Review

The game is exactly what it looks like, except for the end area. You descend 6 levels, have to pick up an orb, and re-climb them all to get out. When you pick up that orb, you have to deal with infinitely re-spawning enemies throughout the 6 levels, and all the care and patience you took in dealing with them before flies out the window. You leveled only health and made sure I had the best weapons, armor, and healing items you could have before taking the orb. It does not matter. You are swarmed with flying skulls that you cannot outrun and must fight. As you do so, Skeleton mages bombard you with magic from beyond the game's very tiny draw distance, and you die. In a game about resource managemeant and dungeon delving, rushing things leads to death, and the game forces you to do so.
I do not recommend this game, and doubt it will be fixed.

Early Access Review

Despite appearances, much of Delver's charm actually manages to stem from the voxel-based imagery. The combat isn't anything to write home about, but certainly keeps things entertaining as  you journey through randomly generated dungeon mazes. As a fan of rogue-likes, it's nice to see a first person one with a focus on melee combat, rather than the usual go-to standards of side-scrolling platformer or Quake-style shoot-em-up. Believe it or not, the music is pretty great, too.

As long as the devs have the foresight to include a jump button and mouse-wheel scrolling in the finished product, this could be a lot of fun.

Early Access Review

--THIS IS A REVIEW OF THE GAME AS OF THE 19TH OF OCTOBER, 2014. THE GAME IS SUBJECT TO CHANGE IN THE FUTURE.--

Now, I shall get all of the potential negatives out of the way first. Yes, the game is light on content. With only a few enemy types and one dungeon, skilled players may find themselves quickly consuming all the game has to offer. That, and some occasional bugs that very rarely appear but can be annoying sometimes.

With that all said, this game is brilliant value for money. £5.59 for a game as addictive as this is a steal, and in my opinion the dev could get away with charging a little more. The pixel art aesthetic is pulled off expertly, as so many other indie dungeon crawlers are from a top down perspective or 2D, it's refreshing to play a FPDC (first person dungeon crawler). The potion system in the game gives a tense atmosphere when you are at low health, having you gamble with fate as you could consume a health potion, or get a poison debuff alongside many other potion effects. Combat is very simple, but this works in the games favour as it makes all combat encounters very quick, which is essential as it makes runs shorter going hand in hand with the permadeath mechanic.

All in all, for the stage it's at now and the price tag it has, this is a great game, and with more content on the way, I highly recommend you buy it now.

Early Access Review

A neat dungeon delve with a charming art style, and quite often, a bit of tension! This is a rougelike crawler that uses randomly generated dungeons to good effect, and can keep you on your toes with the ever looming chance of failure (all gold earned carries over even if you do meet your end during the adventure!). It's easy to pick up and play as the game auto saves every time you exit, and there's included mod support even in the current early access stage.

Delver is shaping up to be a great game, and I can't wait to see future updates the team behind it rolls out!

Early Access Review

--I have bought this game through the Humble Bundle store and thus my playtime here on Steam does not reflect my total playtime of the game.--

This is a praiseworthy game. It's like playing a classic roguelike, the only difference being it's realtime and combat factors in your skill. Combat plays very similarly to Skyrim, and once you understand how to move and chain your attacks I think it's a very solid system.

In terms of loot and magic, it's good. Once you get past the first three floors you will start finding more interesting pieces of equipment.

Graphics are simple but they have a lot of work behind them. Art and lighting are very nice. Sound effects are good enough for the job.

The music is better in some places than in others, but I'd say it's pretty good (especially the more atmospheric pieces down below).

The game as it is is a great bargain. It's a 100% finished game as it stands. And it's good. And it's still being updated.

Early Access Review

Prepare to die.

Alot and often.

And love every minute of it. Explore a mysterious dungeon that will keep you on your toes through all 7 floors (6 of which are randomly generated) of fantasy mayhem.
Arm yourself to the teeth with the best equipment you can pick off your dead enemies and chug every random potion you can find. (Note: results of using said potions may vary. Wildly)
Make it to the final floor (fighting your way through mobs of skeletons) to challenge the dungeon boss. Make it through THAT without dying and the ancient mystical artifact of mysterious mysticism is yours! (As long as you can make it back OUT of the dungeon in one piece.)
Also watch out for mages.

Mages are ♥♥♥♥♥.

The ending is something that must be witnessed to believe, there's TONS of loot that has varying effects on gameplay, and more stuff is on the way in future updates. I bought this game during the madness associated with every Steam sale and THIS is the game I probably regret purchasing the least!

Going into the game, I was put off at first by the simplicity of it. I thought there wouldn't be a way this game could be enagging for more than a couple hours. Oh, how I was wrong. This game is very very fun, and the sense of excitement I get when making it back to the surface is as fresh as the first time I made it. That being said, it's a rougelike, so don't expect to make it out often unless you prepare yourself and manage your inventory.

It's a great game with a bright future and I can't wait to see what else the developers do!

Early Access Review\n\nIt's a lot  like FTL: Short, but very addictive, insanely hard and very easy to die, but your failed runs can still help your next run, and when you think you finally made it to the end, there's a surprise finale you didn't prepare for. I really do like how the RNG traps and potions can be identified without you having to test them on yourself.  Also, poison will bring you to 1 health, but it won't kill you. Just thought you should know.

Early Access Review\n\nThis is a fun time sink right now.  Fought through the levels of the dungeon to get to the orb, picked it up and then all hell broke loose.  Almost made it up a floor but got knifed in the back by a skeleton.  The gold you collect can be used by your future play throughs much like Rogue Legacy.  No other persistence to your characters so far as I can tell.  Great fun though and I really recommend it.  Can't wait for the team to finish it!

Early Access Review

Its Early Access so I'm sure theres lots of things that can happen, but I'm not ready to say its something I'd reccommend. Its been in production for three years and seems like it has a lot to go to make it interesting for more than a couple runthroughs. Random Dungeon Crawling Rogue-Like Game. Its missing something big and its a combination of the mechanics and lack of really any substance that wont let me enjoy it as much as I feel I could.

Pros: Completely random dungeon that works well. RPG Elements. Roguelike, so you never know what you're getting or if you have any chance to succeed. Money Carries over after you die.

Cons: Unrefined interface, no story, visuals are hard on eyes trying to focus between like the 16 bit characters and semi 3D environment, been in development for a long time. No real drive to play through more than a few times.

Overall, i'm not sure what can be added to make it more interesting. The Dev is looking for feedback, but the biggest thing would be to fix the cons. Not sure you you do that with the short playtimes. Why are you there, what are you doing, what is driving you, who are these people, what is the reward, what do I do with all this broken and useless stuff you accumulate, are some good questions to start answering.

-Comiccom

www.thecomic-community.com

Early Access Review

This is unique in genre. It's an FPS roguelike. Others exist, like Paranautical Activity, but I would call that more of an FPS of Binding of Issac, while Delver is more of an FPS version of Nethack. I love Nethack, and have consequently played far too much of it. This solid FPS roguelike will actually fill that same itch in a fresh new way.

The graphics may be offputting, being that they belong more in the Doom era of gaming than they do today, but it is definitely excuted well. And I also do believe that it fits the style of roguelike very well, while allowing the devs to focus on other core gameplay features. And that's where this game really shines. It's built solidly. It may not do a whole ton of things. But the things that it does, it does fantastically.

I believe that if this game were to become as popular as the Dungeons of Dredmor, it could bring in a whole new legion of roguelike fans, as DoD did before it. If procedural generation and first person cameras are what you like, give this a try.

Early Access Review

Delver's art style and gameplay are reminiscent of older titles like Doom and Wolfenstein 3D, but it's most definitely a roguelike. There are a variety of weapons and items to find and use, with potions' effects changing for each playthrough. Though its replayability is not as great as I expected, Delver stays fresh and fun for many, many hours. Its random dungeon generation does provide for a unique experience for each individual delve (heh) into the deep. Overall, this is a very solid game. Heck, this thing is still in Beta.

I can say with absolute certainty that I thoroughly enjoy Delver, and I cannot wait to see what the final product will look like.

Early Access Review\n\nThis game is one of the best First Person pixel games ive seen in a long time. When I first started playing the game I thought of it as tedious and unoriginal. Boy was I wrong, it only seems like alot of other games untill you get further in the dungeons. I had my heart skip a beat at every corner in the sewers. The way that a spider from across the map can echo deep into another part of the cave is spinetingleing. And since once your charecter dies you have to start over you can become legitamently scared for your pixelated life. A few problems I have had though are that the hardest enemy in the game can be bats. They take a lot more hits then they should be able to and have drivin me insane in the deeper levels. This game is glorious and would benefit greatly from Co-Op Multiplayer. But even as a single player game this is a must buy.

Early Access Review

I seem to be playing a lot of Roguelikes recently, and this game is pretty darn good for Early Access.

Your mission is to explore the dungeon and find the orb at the bottommost floor, fighting through groups of people, bugs (ick), bats and skeletons. Get the orb and do your best to escape alive, because everything comes back at you threefold once you pick up the darn thing. The first-person perspective, coupled with a few small corridors and narrow walkways, really give you a mild sense of fear and excitement--you never know what's going to jump out from behind the wall (hopefully not a magic-user).

The game is pretty short. For some players, you could run through the whole thing and escape alive in only about 3 attempts. But don't let that deter you, as it is a lot of fun regardless. That being said, I would strongly suggest picking this game up when it's on sale, as there is a lot to be desired. Still, it IS Early Access...

Also, sometimes I feel like I'm being cheated. I went down there with around 80 arrows, never found a bow, found the orb instead, tried to escape, made it back up to the first floor and FINALLY found a single bow to use the arrows with. Great...

Early Access Review\n\nThis is quite a good game for something that is in beta. It is always frustrating to get a good item and then die because of one of those stupid bats. The best weapon I have found is a excellent iron mace or was it a excellent steel mace? It is good that the game gets updates regularly unlike some games. It is a good game and I think you should buy it while it's cheap.

Early Access Review

Short review: If you like dungeon exploring and the challenge of perma-death, in a game that manages to balance that challenge with enough play to keep you coming back, you shoudl check Delver out.

Long review:

The graphics are Minecraft-like" for lack of a better way to put it. They're 3d 16 bit
recommended: but they work. It definitely adds to the retro feel.\n\nThe gameplay is the same first person dungeon exploration that harkens back to Ultima Underworld. It's balanced and challenging. There is a learning curve but you will find yourself delving deeper on each try and more importantly
hoursPlayed: wanting to try again after each death.\n\nThis is one of the few perma-death games that get it right. It isn't frustrating but also is not easy.  Don't get me wrong
voteText: one moment of stupid can cause a restart but the build to your character is balanced with the difficulty in such a way as to make you avoid mistakes and almost always understand exactly why you died when/where you did. This balance is what makes me want to keep coming back and keeps me trying to delve deeper into the dungeon and hone my skills.\n\nI've tied a lot of these rogue-like games with perma-death recently and this one definitely stands out a a diamond in the rough."

Early Access Review\n\nBean Bag Buccaneers is a two player children's game, the object of which is to pick up your treasure chest on the central island and sail back safely.Each player has a giant sailing ship as their main game piece. Each ship has a removable sail, two trigger-action side panels, and a huge spring-driven cannon. Players take turns moving forward along a prescribed track and shooting bean bags at their opponent's ship. A hit on one of the side panels will force it to pop off and give the player a free shot at the other side; a hit forcing the sail off becalms the ship for a turn.To add to the pirate flavor, each player also has an eye patch. Wearing these will slightly affect depth perception and add a marginal bit of sport to the shooting.This game retailed for the somewhat impressive sum of $16 back in 1962. With its huge plastic ships (close to a foot long), giant vinyl play mat, and the eye patches, it may well stand as one of the more overproduced games of the early 1960s.

Early Access Review\n\nI've enjoyed this game, but it's a tenative recommendation I give with the following advice: try rougelike games first, see if you like them. This puppy's more a dog for fans of Ultima Underworld, for those familiar with the game, than someone looking for a first-person, cartoony Diablo. Which *was* the developer's goal and they need to be commended for their efforts: the game, for what it is, is in my opinion a good but (right now at least) somewhat limited game, and one that's still in development besides. See if you like any of the free rougelike games out there- if not Rouge itself. See if you like games with very little plot to speak of (Doom did have a plot; Super Mario Bros. 3 as well). Read up on Delver and games like it just a bit. And thenm when you're ready, take the plunge: $8 is really quite a deal for a charming little pick-me-up game like this (relatively easy deaths means this game is just one more try" obsession-ready
date: so bear this in mind too). God speed."

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game is very, very nice for early acess/beta. You can think of this like a magical DOOM-like game but when you die, you need a new charcter and everything changes. EVERYTHING changes, including the potions (so red could be instant health or poison as an example) and the levels. The main goal of this game is to the bottom floor to get treasure and to back to the top. Some of the game's mechanics don't work, such as the gold (you can acess shops in the begining, but you die in the dungeon with the gold. Overall I give this game an 8.5/10.

Early Access Review\n\nIt may be a bit difficult but the game is still in development. Its sort of like minecraft only you're going through dungeons and killing things to get to an orb(which takes you back where you started). Every dungeon is also randomly generated. It took me awhile to get to the end and you beat the game once you do. Whenever you die though, you lose everything, but you keep the money you earn. I havent played it since I won, but I will once its updated again. Its definitely worth $7.99 in my opinion. I mean come on, who doesn't like exploring dungeons in a game like this?

Amazing game! Even in Beta, it kicks ♥♥♥ as one of my favorite Dungeon Crawlers. In the short time I've owned it, I've had an amazing experience. Though the graphics aren't that good(I don't think they're meant to be modern high rez graphics) it still provides an amazing, exciting and emersive experience for the player. The graphics are actually quite nostalgic for me;the play style and art brings me back to games like Doom. The music adds so much to it, without it, the game wouldn't be as good. The new art design is awesome, and I love the fact that it is capable of having texture packs! I can see this game lasting for a long time in the community. With the random dungeon generating, it packs so much time for the player to fight, loot, and explore. I actually feel like some bad-♥♥♥ adventurer walking through the halls of monster/bandit/demon infested caves, and its brilliant! One of the best Dungeon Crawlers out there, and I can't wait to see what it's like when it's finished. Great Job!
10/10 Would Play Again! Keep up the good work.

All i can say is BUY IT! I can't explain it it it just is Amazing!

This game is extremely simplistic, and very addictive. It prides itself on its Roguelike qualities while pushing you through the depths of caves, dungeons, and chamber after chamber of increasingly difficult baddies that you have the option of slaying with a plethora of weapon pick-ups -- everything from wands to enchanted daggers and armors --  that increase in power as you do. I couldn't say enough about how much fun I've had in the randomly generated world of underground wonders here in the land of Delver.

Pick it up, boot it up, and you'll have a new experience every single time. The best part is that it's still in Beta!

Early Access Review

Delver is a fantasic Dungeon crawl for a cold night (or any night really) the environment is immersive, the enemies have gone through some nice AI changes to make them a tad smarter than a tea kettle, some even give a nice jump scare when you round a corner and a spider or Telepathic monster is lurking since they don't always make a sound. oh and Bats and caterpillars seem to drop hilariously large heavy items such as a mace or a complete set of mail armour. Love it, most of the other enemies drop coins or potions or minor weapons and armour. But these guys seem to carry a large mace around with them! lol

The envronments are well crafted and quite large. The new maps make the trek more of a challenge as they tend to loop around and take you to cliffs and dead ends sometimes as they are not always straight forward to getting you around the maps.  Also  the maps are randomly generated with a pemadeath element so your never going to have the same playthrough twice as even if you get the same map the items and enemies have also changed and moved around.

The weapons are a standard mish-mash or the usual sort, dagger, sword, hammers, maces and axes, aswell as a few wands. Leveling up is random, your given a choice of 3 skills out of about 6 or so to level up so your not nessasarily able to just level one skill at a time.

Ive played through multiple times and had a blast everytime, 10/10 for this one excited to see the changes as they happen

Early Access Review\n\nWhat's that? You like Rogue-like Dungeon crawlers? What the ♥♥♥♥ are you doing, then? Buy this game. You will not have a regret. Combat is smooth and complete, level design is intriguing, loot is exciting and scarce, randomness of potions is a beautiful mess and overall, this game is pure amazement. Keeping it simple all the while making it more fun. Skills are gained, weapons and armor have stats and enchantments, precious rings and amulets keep you on a search and nomming a slice of bread or cheese once in a while keeps you wanting more. Enemies are interesting to fight as dodging and timing of hits play a key role in the combat system, and not to mention the limiting factors of bow ammunition and wand charges. This is a great game that has undergone a lot of hard work by some very good people, and I'm sure this game is going no where but to victory and improvements on gameplay and story. I give this game a 9.8/10, only because there are an extremely small amount of glitches, which is as expected, and also to the fact that this game does not feel fulling complete. When it is, though, everyone take out your wallets, because if you haven't atleast tried this game, I'll beat you until you can't move your thumb on that joistiq to play COD ever again.

Early Access Review

Reviewing this game as it is still only early access.
I LOVE This game, it is freaking awesome, the old school feeling, the sense of exploration, the sights! However, I know it is still only in early access but I think there needs to be a few things added, such as a slightly larger array of weapons, Toning down the OP-ness of Enemy Magic attacks (Seriously, it will kill you almost instantly with about three hits, when melee attacks to you would usually take only about 10 hits or more) A little bit more variety of elevators and/or secrets such as Buttons to uncover a secret passage, keys to open doors, Maybe add in chests for items, SUPER (That's right, different from the normal!) Secrets, a slightly more diverse Enemy Encounters, Like, more enemies, then again, there is a good selection of enemies already but eh. I don't think maybe adding in the ability to Jump in the game would be a good idea, leave that out, it's a dungeon crawler, no one can jump while crawling. (lol)

What this game is strongest in however is the difficulty, already mentioned how OP enemy magic attacks are, and that needs to be toned down ever so slightly. The sense of exploration is there and is great, the Music (Or ambient noises I guess) REALLY Immerse the player into the game, seriously, sometimes I even get shivers being creeped out, it gives you a sense of danger and fear, Afraid to turn a corner, there have been times I have been jump scared in this game because of the noises almost sounding like they bounce off the walls of the rooms. The inventory system is pretty good, you open the Inventory and the game does not pause, I like that, it gives the player a sense of panic, ESPECIALLY When you are trying to get out a potion of healing (You hope as the potions are randomized each time you play) which means you setting up your inventory bar is CRUCIAL in this game. A thing I would like to see but I kind of have gotten used to, is the ability to use the Mouse Wheel, as haing to use the 1-6 keys on my keyboard have more than once caused me to use a potion when I wanted to use my magic wand.
This game is FREAKING AWESOME, if you were ever in the times of floppy disks, and played those old dungeon crawlers, and love rouge-likes, and having to fear for your life because there is perma-death in the game, this game is your new best friend!

I have a couple of videos so far on the game and making a Let's Play on the game!
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=j5-wPdHgBWk

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=COnzuENBzds

A neat dungeon delve with a charming art style, and quite often, a bit of tension! This is a rougelike crawler that uses randomly generated dungeons to good effect, and can keep you on your toes with the ever looming chance of failure (all gold earned carries over even if you do meet your end during the adventure!). It's easy to pick up and play as the game auto saves every time you exit, and there's included mod support even in the current early access stage.

Delver is shaping up to be a great game, and I can't wait to see future updates the team behind it rolls out!

The game is exactly what it looks like, except for the end area. You descend 6 levels, have to pick up an orb, and re-climb them all to get out. When you pick up that orb, you have to deal with infinitely re-spawning enemies throughout the 6 levels, and all the care and patience you took in dealing with them before flies out the window. You leveled only health and made sure I had the best weapons, armor, and healing items you could have before taking the orb. It does not matter. You are swarmed with flying skulls that you cannot outrun and must fight. As you do so, Skeleton mages bombard you with magic from beyond the game's very tiny draw distance, and you die. In a game about resource managemeant and dungeon delving, rushing things leads to death, and the game forces you to do so.
I do not recommend this game, and doubt it will be fixed.

Early Access Review\n\nDelver is a great game. It takes the roguelike platform and brings it into a charmingly minimalistic yet exciting experience. You may notice the visual similarity to Minecraft. Several people have in fact seen me playing the game and asked if it was Minecraft. Although they look similar, they are completely different. Delver is all about dungeon crawling, getting new gear, and exploring the various randomly generated levels (another Minecraft parallel). The game maintains a perfect balance between frustration and fulfillment. The combat is suspenseful and keeps you on the edge of your seat, and is generally more intense than other roguelikes. The story is fleshed out by miscellaneous notes which you will find in the dungeons, and the various NPCs you may encounter. The storyline is just full enough to keep you interested and immersed; very artfully done. I should also mention the incredible atmosphere, which is held together by the asthetically pleasing visuals and the fantastic soundtrack, which I would definitely purchase if it were an option (take note developers!). Oh, yes, and the development has consistently improved throughout the early access period, which is always a plus. Overall, Delver is a fun and charming little game, which satisfies completely.

On that note I hope to see a Sell Item Button on the shops or have a person that sells and buys. it's not to hard to get down the dungeons and if so is their going to be some number of dungeons where it stops and you get the secret object at the end of the maze". If there is a story behind this all i would want to see places such as villages and not just dungeons which gets eh after being to over powered to kill with potions and heavy gear."

Early Access Review\n\nI love this game, it's more than worth the cheap price and it is a great time waster. I've spent quite a bit more time on this game than Steam says, on both my Mac and PC and it runs perfectly on both. Which is saying a lot when most games can not run more than 20fps on low graphics settings on my Macbook Pro. You can hardly tell that this game is still in alpha as I have not come across any bugs or issues. The only issue I have with this game is the fact that when I die I lose all of my stuff and any of my upgrades and have to start from the beginning. I understand that this is a feature of the game, but I would really love it if the developers made a game mode for players like me who do not really enjoy perma-death games and would rather have a fun dungeon crawler where I can save my progress. I would still recommend this game to anyone looking for a fun little first person dungeon crawler.

Maybe I enjoy Delver too much. I run DirectX 11 games all the time, but I love new games that look old, run on low end hardware and feel freshly improved over archaic games.

Controls are smooth, simple and the old school look is still colorful and pretty. Soundtrack is appropriate.

I'm not crazy about permadeath, but it doesn't ruin the game really. This is Early Access so it's obviously not finished, but if I were able to travel an open world in this (like an Elder Scrolls game) along with some tweaks I would play this more than most of the 'next gen' games out there.

I don't usually review a game until I've played it for quite a while but I will already say that Delver exceeds my expectations and is well worth your time and money. It's got a ton of character and is a great game to challenge yourself with as it really does make you proceed with caution. The deaths I've experienced so far are all due to me rushing into a new area and getting trapped by new mechanics I didn't expect. It doesn't feel cheap at all, rather it makes me kick myself and start again. I can't rave about the simple graphics enough. This is a game that uses its style to its advantage and never feels like it's simply cashing in on retro pixel art. Also, it looks even better when you're playing than when you're simply watching videos. I can't explain that one.

I know this is currently in Early Access but I can't help but feel I've encountered a polished game. Even if nothing changes, I can see myself coming back to this one.

Excellent first-person, rogue-like, not too pixelated-pixelated, dungeon explorer. I love the music and how some enemies seem to come out of  nowhere. This game is great if you like an fps/rpg/rogue-like, minimalist game and don't easily get nausiated from erratic user-mouse movement (because that's kinda my style). It's less pixelated than Home so it doesn't mess with my vision once I look away from my screen. Although when enemies get right in front of your face they get a little distorted but I'm sure that was intended by the developers and adds a nice flavor to the gameplay. Overall, super fun. One of the best early access games I've purchased regardless of the fact that I bought it on sale.

There has been a little bit of clipping through walls (throwing items directly into a wall at about a 30 degree angle and hallways that loop around) but it's in parts that I can't tell if it was intentional or not so this is not a negative comment, more so a random add-on to my review.

Early Access Review

In my own opinion (please don't hate me internets) this is one of the best roguelike games out there.

The art style is charming, the music is catchy, and the environments keep the dungeon from getting to stale and repetitive.  I've been playing this game since it was in the alpha stages before it was even on Steam, and every time an update is released, it introduces new and exciting features to the game.

One of the strongest features though is the balance between difficulty, length, and permadeath.  The game isn't tremendously long, but it is quite challenging.  This is fantastic because when you win it feels like an accomplishment, but if you die it isn't a crippling blow as you were probably only 3-6 floors down.  Another 20 or 30 minutes and you could potentially get there again.

This game is a hidden gem of the indie developer scene and I sincerely hope it receives the recognition it deserves.

Early Access Review\n\nThis game is nothing like minecraft... there I needed to get that out of the way.... from the charming graphics to the somewhat challenging enemies and neat weapons, this game is quite fun for an early access game. Early Access Review\n\nThis is a really cool sort of fusion between a dungeon crawler and an old school FPS. The mechanics are simple but build nicely, and flow nicely throughout the pace of the game. This game constantly Evolves.
the Devs still work on it steadily, always adding new content!

I LOVE this Dungeon Crawler, there are so few like it.



PROS:
- Kill it, Loot it, Save it, Use it, and repeat.

that so far is the only con to this game, but when you realy think about it,

Pretty fun Rouge-like game! I adore the pixal graphics and random potion effects! Lets start off with the Pros!
Pros:
-Progressively gets difficult
-Always different Potion effects
-Traps!
-Loot/Spells/Majik
- Nice Graphics
- Gold carries over death (Im not sure on this one but I think)
- Always different Dungeons
- Some weapons are faster then others!
- Secret Passageways
-GIANT AREAS!

Now to the cons! Not that many because this is a great game!
Cons:
- Wizards are too OP for me
- Wands have really low charges like 6 per use
- Cant really chose what perk you want to upgrade you get 3 choices you can choose from everytime you level!
- Poison effect seems a little TOO OP
- Shop is a little pricey (But gold might carry over)

Overall this game is fanastic! I recommand this game anyone who feels like going head first into a random dungeon! I also love reading the notes sometimes! Some of the secrets of the dungeons I still have not figured out! I will be looking into more hours on this then the current 4 hours!

Now to my review.
Imagine games like Dungeons of Dredmore in first person. Thats pretty much what this game is. Dungeoncrawling. Kill enemies, collect their drop, manage your healthpotions and food, get the legendary item and make your whole way back in an even harder dungeon than before.

One Run is pretty short, but much longer than a run in a game like binding of isaac. Sadly there is not much in this game to play it (for me) a third time. I will check it out with a new patch/update or at least at full realease.

I can recommend this game.

Short answer, it's great. Long answer?
I actually used to play this way back when it had 8x8 graphics and had just added potions on my laptop and Android phone. It was wicked fun then, and it's just gotten better. Like Eldritch? You'll like this. Like Minecraft? Ditto. If you ever played a roguelike, and wanted it to move just a little bit faster, this is for you. The beta kind of lends itself to a charm, though the frequent updates mean that occasionally your save files will be completely lost. If you're not a fan of that, wait til it's done. But if you want an original dungeoncrawler with a dearth of story and a ton of heart? This is for you.

Early Access Review\n\nA simple dungeon diving game where you need to reach the last floor and find the orb! The catch is...there is no instant teleport out. Oh no no no...that would be too easy. You must fight your way out! Being chased by the forces in the dark while trying to not get yourself lost or dead. It will take some time to get to the final floor, but that is the challange of the game. With each new update the AI's get smarter and that is what I like. The game used to be too easy but then it was patched and now it is worth the dungeon diving! Be scared, cuacious, or just flat out bold and daring. You will find upgrades along the way! Well worth the time that was put into it.

Early Access Review\n\nI believe I have DELVED in far enough into the game to write my review in its current state. (heh). Delver is a rogue-like dungeon crawler with RPG elements. The art style is personalized and enjoyable to just sit there and look at for a while. But lets get to the nitty gritty. Delver still is very much still in early access. A successful run will take a little more than an hour and its replay ability is good but not that great once you beat the game. The combat is enjoyable but mabeye a bit simplistic and becomes much easier once you learn the movement system. My one big complaint is the ending when you fight the Lich. He only took 4 shots from my 11-18 damadge bow and just nuked you when you were near him tons of damadge. He felt more like a place holder than a real boss. Also when you have to climb back up to the surface it felt like filler and you could just run around the enemys till you got to the top for the most part. In the end Delver is a bit of an investment and at its current state a few hour's of fun.( Have not checked out any mods but apparently the community is great and that would add some time to your hour's)  It's your choice if you want to Invest in this but if your not sure I would wait and follow its development untill it came to a state that you liked, but if the idea really hits home with you pick it up and join the Delver community.

Early Access Review\n\nBean Bag Buccaneers is a two player children's game, the object of which is to pick up your treasure chest on the central island and sail back safely.Each player has a giant sailing ship as their main game piece. Each ship has a removable sail, two trigger-action side panels, and a huge spring-driven cannon. Players take turns moving forward along a prescribed track and shooting bean bags at their opponent's ship. A hit on one of the side panels will force it to pop off and give the player a free shot at the other side; a hit forcing the sail off becalms the ship for a turn.To add to the pirate flavor, each player also has an eye patch. Wearing these will slightly affect depth perception and add a marginal bit of sport to the shooting.This game retailed for the somewhat impressive sum of $16 back in 1962. With its huge plastic ships (close to a foot long), giant vinyl play mat, and the eye patches, it may well stand as one of the more overproduced games of the early 1960s.

Early Access Review

Delver is an addictive first-person Rogue-like, which implies randomization and permanent death -- you will lose your save data if you die. The graphics are fairly simple, being LWJGL (nerd talk), but have recently been updated into amazing pixel art that it beautiful to look at. Gameplay is pretty simple, based around a set of attributes, which from my memory, are Attack, Speed, Health, Magic, Agility, and Defense. You can change these around when you level up.

This game is not a role-playing game, or at least, it isn't by my view of the term. You won't be having thoughtful talk with the bandits encompassing the first two floors of the seven-floor dungeon -- you will instead smack them multiple times with your warhammer until they die. It has a story that's only implied, and is quite open to exploration: something about undead being raised with an orb.

I absolutely recommend this game to action RPG lovers everywhere, and it's only going to get better, because it's still Early Access; it'll get updated!

Early Access Review

Delver is a roguelike- it's your basic dungeon crawler with permadeath in a somewhat generic fantasy setting that mostly impresses with a charming retro pixel look. That look, however, may be enough to get you interested.

As always, story is trivial and not even worth bothering about; there is a dungeon, there is a MacGuffin to retrieve from the dungeon, there are many enemies between you and said MacGuffin, and that's it.

Each game drops you in front of the dungeon, where a small camp has been set up; your equipment is chosen from a small random pool of low-quality weapon and armour, and then you delve in.

Navigating the labyrinth is easy and smooth, and the game instantly reminded me of Minecraft and Eldritch; it has the same blocky pixel look and oddly warped architecture. Older players will also think of Ultima Underworld (if UU had taken place in a more cartoonish world). Move with mouse and WASD, pick up and interact with E, attack with Space or Mouse, that's it; no jumping, crouching or extra casting buttons. It's simple yet effective.

Combat can be a bit botchy. Melee attacks can be charged" to deal more damage
date: archery and spellcasting from wands or scrolls is straightforward
recommended: but there is no crosshair at all and it can take a while to adjust to that- I found myself constantly aiming too low to actually hit my targets. With a melee weapon that means a missed swing
hoursPlayed: but wasting a wand charge just because you didn't connect with the collision box hurts. The controls themselves
helpfulPercent: are precise and reliable so you'll get used to it eventually.\n\nKilling enemies gives you money and loot and also experience; once you level up you can beef up your attributes as usual. Even a single extra point in speed or attack has noticeable impact on the game
votesTotal: and that is a welcome touch. No need to put several points into an attribute before it pays off
votesFunny: you instantly benefit from your investment.\n\nDifficulty is absolutely okay- a bit on the "hard" side but that's what one expects from a roguelike. The permadeath is slightly softened by the fact that you keep your money; after a while the coins allow you to buy some better starting gear in the camp
commentsCount: so you enter a new dungeon with better equipment and better chances to make it deeper.\n\nSo you have a roguelike that does nothing new. It absolutely delivers what you expect from the genre
column16: dresses it in nice retro graphics and runs with it. It's more charming than breathtaking
column17: more "familar fun" than the next brand new indie hit. It's worth checking out if you like a fun dungeon romp.\n\nDelver's also still in development
column18: so take into account that there's clearly MORE to come."

But let me remind you, when you die. You die. You loose your items and start over. BUTTTTTTT.......You keep your gold from your previous spelunks. And gold can be used at camp" to get a bit of a head start. Its worth all of the cost. Plus

recommended: memory wize they are about the same. Have fun."

Early Access Review

It's good. I haven't finished it yet, but I'm gonna give some pros and cons.

Pros:
Even though the graphics are pixelated, they're still really good. It has its own charm.
The music is fitting and catchy.
The atmosphere is excellent.
The weapons are unique.
The game is a good price.
Randomly generated dungeons are built well.

Cons:
Hitboxes on enemies are VERY strange. You have to be very close to attack them, even with a longsword. They always seem to have an advantage when it comes to melee. That's my main complaint.
When you get to the level-up screen, I can't pick anything or close the window. The only way past it is to quit the game and reload your save.
From the reviews I've read, the game is short.

In conclusion, Delver is a good game. It'll definetely keep me coming back. I'd reccomend this game to people who like dungeon crawlers or the Elder Scrolls series.

This game is extremely simplistic, and very addictive. It prides itself on its Roguelike qualities while pushing you through the depths of caves, dungeons, and chamber after chamber of increasingly difficult baddies that you have the option of slaying with a plethora of weapon pick-ups -- everything from wands to enchanted daggers and armors --  that increase in power as you do. I couldn't say enough about how much fun I've had in the randomly generated world of underground wonders here in the land of Delver.

Pick it up, boot it up, and you'll have a new experience every single time. The best part is that it's still in Beta!

Early Access Review\n\nIf you like gritty, 8-bit style retro dungeon crawlers, then you'll love this game.  The levels are surprisingly dynamic for the overall very simplistic style of the game, however, I found myself  trapped in the gameplay.  There are a few minor quirks that I think could be worked on to improve the controls, but overall, the game is casual, yet difficult enough that it keeps you working. So far, I would give this game around a 7.5/10.

They'll do 10 HP Points of damage, leaving you with about 3 or 4 HP points left, if you're low level. But, all in all, decent game. I'd like to see it grow. 7/10

Delver is a 3D rogue-like game with randomly generating dungeons, and a randomly generated starting inventory each time you start a new game, making each playthrough fairly unique.
Hopefully, future update will make the game a bit longer, as finishing it (without counting the failed tries) can easily be done in just a few minutes.

However, I did have quite a lot of fun in this game, discovering new dungeons and loot every time I played.
Also, this game has a texture pack by Sphax already, which gives me hopes for future mods or even more texture packs (hopefully though, these ones will be free...).

Overall, this is a fun and good game if you don't wanna get involved for countless hours of playing. A new game of Delver is always fun to play, and with the high amount of updates, there are lots of new things to discover.

Oh, and you can eat some steak you looted from a dead zombie. 10/10.

Delver is a fantasic Dungeon crawl for a cold night (or any night really) the environment is immersive, the enemies have gone through some nice AI changes to make them a tad smarter than a tea kettle, some even give a nice jump scare when you round a corner and a spider or Telepathic monster is lurking since they don't always make a sound. oh and Bats and caterpillars seem to drop hilariously large heavy items such as a mace or a complete set of mail armour. Love it, most of the other enemies drop coins or potions or minor weapons and armour. But these guys seem to carry a large mace around with them! lol

The envronments are well crafted and quite large. The new maps make the trek more of a challenge as they tend to loop around and take you to cliffs and dead ends sometimes as they are not always straight forward to getting you around the maps.  Also  the maps are randomly generated with a pemadeath element so your never going to have the same playthrough twice as even if you get the same map the items and enemies have also changed and moved around.

The weapons are a standard mish-mash or the usual sort, dagger, sword, hammers, maces and axes, aswell as a few wands. Leveling up is random, your given a choice of 3 skills out of about 6 or so to level up so your not nessasarily able to just level one skill at a time.

Ive played through multiple times and had a blast everytime, 10/10 for this one excited to see the changes as they happen

Early Access Review\n\nWhat's that? You like Rogue-like Dungeon crawlers? What the ♥♥♥♥ are you doing, then? Buy this game. You will not have a regret. Combat is smooth and complete, level design is intriguing, loot is exciting and scarce, randomness of potions is a beautiful mess and overall, this game is pure amazement. Keeping it simple all the while making it more fun. Skills are gained, weapons and armor have stats and enchantments, precious rings and amulets keep you on a search and nomming a slice of bread or cheese once in a while keeps you wanting more. Enemies are interesting to fight as dodging and timing of hits play a key role in the combat system, and not to mention the limiting factors of bow ammunition and wand charges. This is a great game that has undergone a lot of hard work by some very good people, and I'm sure this game is going no where but to victory and improvements on gameplay and story. I give this game a 9.8/10, only because there are an extremely small amount of glitches, which is as expected, and also to the fact that this game does not feel fulling complete. When it is, though, everyone take out your wallets, because if you haven't atleast tried this game, I'll beat you until you can't move your thumb on that joistiq to play COD ever again.

Early Access Review\n\nThis game is super fun but a little bit buggy. Got stuck in a wall after about 20 minutes of playing, but having a dungeon crawler in the style of Minecraft is amazing. Once the final version is released and the bugs are kinked out, I'd give it a 10/10.

The game is fun and intuitive but I have to say I docked points for finding a trap in a hallway I couldn't avoid in any way; The game doesn't allow you to jump and the way the tile was positioned it wouldn't let me pass without walking over the plate. Having to budget health for gauranteed damage from traps in a roguelike is like trying to pay your mortgage payment with dryer lint. You just don't have the ability to do that. However, I will be willing to play the game some more if I discover that was a very uncommon situation; IE, up until the point I encounter that problem again. If you enjoy roguelikes and you really liked the Might & Magic 1st person adventure games, you'll enjoy Delver.

Update (Spoiler Warning): It is possible to deal with most traps without stepping on them even if they are between you and the path you need to go down, but there are still areas and configurations where they will always hit you, even if you try to disable them. Still holding my thumb up but sequels will need some tweaking.

Early Access Review

Delver really brings me back to Daggerfall, it's a fun little randomly-generated dungeon crawler. Enviroments stay fresh, no two playthroughs are alike. Each dungeon level brings new elements and enemies, from easier mages and warriors at the beginning to tough undead enemies at the lower levels. Enemy AI is surprisingly smart for game like this, damage an enemy and it will retreat, prepare to swing and the enemy will move to dodge, etc. It's a nice contrast to a game like Minecraft where enemies are programmed to just walk into you until you die. At the ruins level, the difficulty curve spikes, so some tactical thinking is required. You can't just run and gun, and I found myself taking advantage of things like corners and different enemy positions. Delver is a roguelike, so it features perma-death. You can't make your decisions lightly, and that's a good thing.

The game has only been out for a few months and it is still in beta so there is still room for improvement. You're essentially restricted to playing a battlemage; the drop rates for things like weapons, wands and scrolls are completely random so you'll need to use a mix of everything to succeed. I think an item that allows the player to recharge an empty wand would help with that. I wish there was a bit more variation in the enemies, it's currently limited to about four or five types per-dungeon-type and some of them (like bats) can start to become annoying after a while. Potions very useful but their stats are generated randomly with every new playthrough, so you need to determine their stats through trial-and-error. If you don't have the food or health/restore potions to afford you the ability to test new potions out, you ignore them, and they start to build up in your inventory. I love the randomly-generated aspect of this game but if they were color-coded (red for health, blue for magic, etc.) and still used randomly generated stats it would make using potions more convenient.

Those are just minor things though, Delver is still a great indie title with a lot of potential and I'd highly reccomend it, especially if you're a fan of the early Elder Scrolls titles.

Early Access Review

Delver, mechanically, is a great, great game. I've had a ton of fun with it so far, and I'd recommend it to just about anyone. Right now it's pretty small, but I have high hopes for it when the full game is released.

The combat is very reminiscent of Minecraft, especially the swords and bows, though somewhat more complex. Elemental magic wands are an interesting option, though they're all basically the same. Enemies don't seem to have resistances or weaknesses, and there are no additional effects like the fire wand making enemies catch fire. Still, this is obviously an area the developers plan to expand on in the future, so I'm excited to see what they might add to the combat system.

The visuals are really great. There's a satisfying feeling in smashing an enemy backwards and watching him burst into a shower of red pixels, and the various enemies and environments all look fantastic. I was pleasantly surprised by the variety in the different dungeons you trek through. Cave levels are uneven and winding; a sewer I found myself in seemed extremely linear at first, but turned out to have tons of little alcoves and branching paths. Enemies all attack in similar ways (charging forward with melee weapons or shooting magic), but at this point in development it's nice to have some various enemy looks.

Honestly, this is a great game by itself. It just needs more... stuff. More content. The levels are pretty linear overall, and the end goal is fairly simple. Some other objectives could be fun... you could happen upon a corpse, with a clue that a great treasure lies hidden nearby. Find it, and you might be rewarded with some powerful armor, or a legendary magic wand. Special named weapons and armor would be so fun to collect, it would keep you coming back into the dungeons for more. I'd also love to see bigger levels, with multiple parts.

As of right now, this is a great base for a game. Once they add more content, supporting the already great gameplay with some additional items and places, this could become a favorite.

Early Access Review\n\nAs a person who seems to undeniably enjoy nearly every Rogue-like Game I pick, this one is no exception. It has quite beautiful throwback to classic Apogee/3D Realms FPS Shooters. While it's still in Beta at the time of writing this, it has great potential and a lot going for it if the Dev(s) continues to polish and expand on the content. I don't have any real gripes with it so far, aside from a bug I had when leveling, but seemed to be resolved by playing in Fullscreen. The artwork, in spite of being 8-bit Pixel Art with some 3D rendering, the graphics are beautiful, the controls seem well polished, and the combat is pretty smooth. Though combat is pretty monotonous, there's not much else you can realy expect from a Rogue-like, in which your objective is to NOT DIE. All in all, good game. Give the Devs' your support; Buy the Game.

Early Access Review

Simple Review  here:

Delver is a rogue-like dungeon crawler where the player's only goal is to get to the bottom of the dungeon (7th floor), grab the Yithidian Orb, and return to the surface with it. What's the catch? Well I'm glad you asked. As previously stated, there are 7 floors in total. The first two are the Dungeons, the next two are the Caves, the next two are the Sewers, and the final stage is the dreaded Ruins. This game can have a somewhat steep learning curve, but it is very fun because each playthrough is an entirely new experience. Here's why. The dungeons are all procedurally generated (which means you get entirely new maps every time you play), the items one may acquire vary in quality and location, and all potions change in their function. The red potion may be healing or magic resistance the first time through, but it may be poison or physical damage resistance the next time through. These qualities are what make this game a Rogue-like. This is also a First Person game and there are NO PUZZLES for those of you who hate puzzles haha.

Pros:
+ The graphics are very well done, stylized in a 16-bit, pixelated vibe.
+ The music is very pleasing and enjoyable. It is fitting for floor's theme and atmospheric as well.
+ The controls are simple and easy to learn.
+ The game makes leaps and bounds with every update provided.
+ It has a surprisingly addictive learning curve.
+ Difficulty is good enough to where you may finally beat the game one time, but when you go back to try again you can't make it.
+Enemy AI is good. The various enemies have various attack patterns and styles, even methods of movement.
+ A somewhat complex weapon system in which there are several types of weapons such as the bow, wand, hammer (2-hands), and long sword just to name a few. Each weapon has its own knockback, damage, and range.
+ The leveling system is unique in this game in that you get to choose from 3 randomly chosen stats out of 6 total stats: Agility, Attack, Defense, Health, Magic, and Speed.
+ Can create various character builds according to the stats you want, the stats your given each level up, and the amount of armor you choose to wear.
+ Armor affects speed and defense: The more defense, the less speed in general.
+ Tons of replay value and plenty of good texture packs and mods to extend the game and make it more challenging. . . even adding new types of floors and enemies!
+ Items do not carry over after death, but gold does.
+ I greatly enjoy how you start at a base camp every time that contains two vendors who can sell you things after you collect enough gold in the dungeon. If you're lucky, you may come a cross a vendor in one of the first two floors as well.

Cons:
- There are still a few bugs to work out such as items randomly getting stuck in walls and making this atrocious sound that cuts out the music for the rest of your journey.
- Another bug would be the bow sometimes passing right through enemies or just bouncing off. Some of the enemies may just have ridiculous hit boxes (looking at you floating eye).
- Other than those two bugs, I never really came across anything that was bad or wrong.
- Pick your poison here: Runs can take you anywhere from 30 minutes (if you're really good and have lots of experience) to 1 hour and 30 minutes or longer (if you're a noob).
- For some players, the luck factor that comes in to play when discovering gear, the distance from the entrance of a floor to the exit of a floor, and the number of enemies that spawn, may not be entirely enjoyable as it will feel as if the odds are against you a bit too strongly at times.

Overall, this game is a whole lot of fun and well worth every penny spent. The creator updates relatively often and they are usually massive updates when he does. He keeps everyone informed of his goals with the game and where it is headed. It's a very good challenge and you can quit and pick it back up at any time. I personally love playing it casually while listening to some of my favorite music. It's a very relaxing, but still energetic experience.

Early Access Review\n\nOkay, so I originally downloaded this game back during it's open Alpha (Or beta, not entirely sure) stage in development when it was just a free 8-bit thing, and it was amazing. Sure the gameplay was simplistic, but that was to be expected. So a few years later I was kinda suprised that when I found this game was on Steam, as I handn't heard anything about it for a long time. So I bought it, and was amazed with what the game had become. The textures had been changed from 8 to 16 bits, and are really well designed. I'm also loving the tons of new enemies and weapons, as well as the possobility of shops in the overworld now. Admittedly the game is still pretty hard the further you go, so I have yet to have enough gold to test these shops, but it doesn't take anything away from the gameplay. On the note of difficulty, I'm also not sure of how many more dungeons they've added (There was only one in alpha, but that's definetly changed). There are a few issues here and there, (Throwing a fire wand into the water broke the sounds for me) but this game is still in early acess, so that's kinda to be expected. But compared to alot of the stuff that is on early acess, this is easily one of the best things I've seen in here to date.

Early Access Review

I have owned this game on mobile for ome time now, and I just recently bought the game on Steam. Let me say, this game does not disappoint. I got the game on sale, but the price of 7.99$ USD is totally reasonable. Here is why:

-Great, Motivated Developers (Updates are Frequent, but not too frequent. I.E. Once a month-ish)
-Loads of Combat (Lots of different weapons to try, ranging from Bows to Maces)
-Lots of Hidden Lore (Notes are scattered about the Dungeon, hinting about the games Lore)
-Lots of Monsters (Fight Mobs ranging from Spiders to One-Eyed Flying Things)
-Appealing Graphics (Nice Retro feel, texture packs are avalible)
-Wonderful Music (Very peaceful at times, makes you want to adventure)
-Procedurly Generated Dungeons and Caves (Caves and Dungeons are Generated on spawn, every world is different)

The frequent updates, music, and graphics of this game really get you in the mood for dungeon running, and it feals so rewarding to climb down the ladder to the next floor. Prepare to sink many hours trekking through dungeons, and when your character dies in an epic battle against a small bat, to instantly set off on another trip through a whole new dungeon.

My only complaint is the fact that the scroll wheel doesn't allow you to navigate the hotbar.

Also, saw a Doge painting. 10/10

Early Access Review\n\nI believe this game has a pretty solid base. Graphical style reminded me of Ultima Underworld, combat felt like Magicite combined with Minecraft, and that all got dropped into a simple stat roguelike game. Combat was pretty fair and can be pretty unforgiving if you aren't careful. That said, I believe this game needs some serious difficulty boosts via bosses and more dangerous traps. Cleared the whole game in roughly 110 minutes on the first try. Second thing I feel would make it more interesting would be the addition of more secret doors and maybe optional puzzles.

Early Access Review\n\nIt's not entirely unlike Dungeon Crawl: Stone Soup, in the style and story (1. Reach bottom of dungeon; 2. Grab shiny orb of arbitrary unexplained power; 3. GTFO while being pursued by respawning enemies). However, Delver is a much shorter and more straightforward game, and is a real-time roguelike rather than a turn-based one. But despite, or perhaps because of, its short length (7 floors, easily completable in an hour or two) it is incredibly fun. It has the right amount of RNG; enough to keep things fresh with new layouts and items, but not so much that you can ever really get wrecked by random factors beyond your control. Every run feels winnable; every death feels like it could have been avoided if you had just played better. Plus it has a level editor now, and is still under active development, so there's lots of potential for more things in the future.

Early Access Review

I seem to be playing a lot of Roguelikes recently, and this game is pretty darn good for Early Access.

Your mission is to explore the dungeon and find the orb at the bottommost floor, fighting through groups of people, bugs (ick), bats and skeletons. Get the orb and do your best to escape alive, because everything comes back at you threefold once you pick up the darn thing. The first-person perspective, coupled with a few small corridors and narrow walkways, really give you a mild sense of fear and excitement--you never know what's going to jump out from behind the wall (hopefully not a magic-user).

The game is pretty short. For some players, you could run through the whole thing and escape alive in only about 3 attempts. But don't let that deter you, as it is a lot of fun regardless. That being said, I would strongly suggest picking this game up when it's on sale, as there is a lot to be desired. Still, it IS Early Access...

Also, sometimes I feel like I'm being cheated. I went down there with around 80 arrows, never found a bow, found the orb instead, tried to escape, made it back up to the first floor and FINALLY found a single bow to use the arrows with. Great...

recommended: but they work. It definitely adds to the retro feel.\n\nThe gameplay is the same first person dungeon exploration that harkens back to Ultima Underworld. It's balanced and challenging. There is a learning curve but you will find yourself delving deeper on each try and more importantly
hoursPlayed: wanting to try again after each death.\n\nThis is one of the few perma-death games that get it right. It isn't frustrating but also is not easy.  Don't get me wrong

This balance is what makes me want to keep coming back and keeps me trying to delve deeper into the dungeon and hone my skills.\n\nI've tied a lot of these rogue-like games with perma-death recently and this one definitely stands out a a diamond in the rough."

Early Access Review

--I have bought this game through the Humble Bundle store and thus my playtime here on Steam does not reflect my total playtime of the game.--

This is a praiseworthy game. It's like playing a classic roguelike, the only difference being it's realtime and combat factors in your skill. Combat plays very similarly to Skyrim, and once you understand how to move and chain your attacks I think it's a very solid system.

In terms of loot and magic, it's good. Once you get past the first three floors you will start finding more interesting pieces of equipment.

Graphics are simple but they have a lot of work behind them. Art and lighting are very nice. Sound effects are good enough for the job.

The music is better in some places than in others, but I'd say it's pretty good (especially the more atmospheric pieces down below).

The game as it is is a great bargain. It's a 100% finished game as it stands. And it's good. And it's still being updated.

Early Access Review

Reviewing this game as it is still only early access.
I LOVE This game, it is freaking awesome, the old school feeling, the sense of exploration, the sights! However, I know it is still only in early access but I think there needs to be a few things added, such as a slightly larger array of weapons, Toning down the OP-ness of Enemy Magic attacks (Seriously, it will kill you almost instantly with about three hits, when melee attacks to you would usually take only about 10 hits or more) A little bit more variety of elevators and/or secrets such as Buttons to uncover a secret passage, keys to open doors, Maybe add in chests for items, SUPER (That's right, different from the normal!) Secrets, a slightly more diverse Enemy Encounters, Like, more enemies, then again, there is a good selection of enemies already but eh. I don't think maybe adding in the ability to Jump in the game would be a good idea, leave that out, it's a dungeon crawler, no one can jump while crawling. (lol)

What this game is strongest in however is the difficulty, already mentioned how OP enemy magic attacks are, and that needs to be toned down ever so slightly. The sense of exploration is there and is great, the Music (Or ambient noises I guess) REALLY Immerse the player into the game, seriously, sometimes I even get shivers being creeped out, it gives you a sense of danger and fear, Afraid to turn a corner, there have been times I have been jump scared in this game because of the noises almost sounding like they bounce off the walls of the rooms. The inventory system is pretty good, you open the Inventory and the game does not pause, I like that, it gives the player a sense of panic, ESPECIALLY When you are trying to get out a potion of healing (You hope as the potions are randomized each time you play) which means you setting up your inventory bar is CRUCIAL in this game. A thing I would like to see but I kind of have gotten used to, is the ability to use the Mouse Wheel, as haing to use the 1-6 keys on my keyboard have more than once caused me to use a potion when I wanted to use my magic wand.
This game is FREAKING AWESOME, if you were ever in the times of floppy disks, and played those old dungeon crawlers, and love rouge-likes, and having to fear for your life because there is perma-death in the game, this game is your new best friend!

I have a couple of videos so far on the game and making a Let's Play on the game!
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=j5-wPdHgBWk

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=COnzuENBzds

Early Access Review

A neat dungeon delve with a charming art style, and quite often, a bit of tension! This is a rougelike crawler that uses randomly generated dungeons to good effect, and can keep you on your toes with the ever looming chance of failure (all gold earned carries over even if you do meet your end during the adventure!). It's easy to pick up and play as the game auto saves every time you exit, and there's included mod support even in the current early access stage.

Delver is shaping up to be a great game, and I can't wait to see future updates the team behind it rolls out!

Overtime though I have found it to be a much more polished game than when it initially came out. I would just go into it knowing that you are getting a basic arrive at a dungeon and move through it killing monsters until the end" type of game and not a more loot based "diablo type" game."
